IN ADDITION, THE AKVDRS MAINTAINS AN ADVISORY GROUP INCLUSIVE OF REPRESENTATIVES FROM ALL KEY DATA PROVIDERS, FEDERAL/STATE/MUNICIPAL AGENCIES, ACADEMIA, TRIBAL AND PUBLIC HEALTH ORGANIZATIONS, BEHAVIORAL AND MENTAL HEALTH PRACTITIONERS, PREVENTION SPECIALISTS AND OTHER STAKEHOLDERS AND DATA USERS. THE AKVDRS MAINTAINS QUALITY ASSURANCE AND EVALUATION PROCESSES IN ACCORDANCE WITH CDC GUIDELINES.    THE AKVDRS DATA IS DISSEMINATED VIA SEVERAL FORMATS AND SCHEDULES INCLUDING EPIDEMIOLOGY BULLETINS, REPORTS, ELECTRONIC DASHBOARD (IBIS), AND OTHER MEDIA FORMATS, PEER-REVIEW ARTICLES, AND FORMAL PRESENTATIONS AT STATE AND NATIONAL CONFERENCES.

UTAH VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM - THE UTAH VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM (UTVDRS) HAS BEEN OPERATING SINCE 2005. UTAH HAS SUCCESSFULLY ABSTRACTED DATA FOR THE UTVDRS USING THE GUIDELINES, CASE DEFINITIONS, AND DATA ELEMENTS PROVIDED BY THE CDC FOR THE LAST 17 YEARS. DATA IS ROUTINELY COLLECTED FROM THE CORE DATA SOURCES WHICH CONSIST OF MEDICAL EXAMINER REPORTS FROM THE OFFICE OF THE MEDICAL EXAMINER (OME), DEATH CERTIFICATES FROM THE OFFICE OF VITAL RECORDS AND STATISTICS, POLICE REPORTS FROM OVER 150 LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCIES, AND SUPPLEMENTARY HOMICIDE AND CRIME LAB REPORTS FROM THE DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SAFETY.  DATA FROM THESE SOURCES INCLUDE VICTIM AND SUSPECT DEMOGRAPHICS, CIRCUMSTANCES SURROUNDING THE VIOLENT INCIDENT, WEAPON INFORMATION, AND THE RELATIONSHIP BETWEEN THE VICTIM AND SUSPECT.  THE OVERALL KEY OUTCOMES FOR THIS PROJECT ARE: 1) IMPROVED COMPLETENESS, TIMELINESS, AND QUALITY OF VIOLENT DEATH SURVEILLANCE DATA; 2) STRONGER RELATIONSHIPS WITH KEY PARTNERS; 3) INCREASED ACCESS TO NVDRS DATA BY THE PUBLIC AND PARTNERS TO INFORM THEIR VIOLENCE AND POSSIBLY INJURY PREVENTION ACTIVITIES; 4) INCREASED USE OF VIOLENT DEATH SURVEILLANCE DATA BY PARTNERS TO INFORM VIOLENCE PREVENTION PROGRAMMATIC AND POLICY DECISIONS; 5) INCREASED ABILITY TO DESCRIBE THE GEOGRAPHIC DISTRIBUTION OF VIOLENT DEATHS AND UNDERSTAND THE SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH IN RELATION TO VIOLENT DEATH-RELATED HEALTH DISPARITIES. OVER TIME THESE OUTCOMES, COUPLED WITH RESOURCES, ARE INTENDED TO REDUCE VIOLENCE BY INCREASING THE ABILITY OF VIOLENCE PREVENTION PARTNERS TO INFORM, DESIGN, AND IMPLEMENT EFFECTIVE VIOLENCE PREVENTION PROGRAMS AND POLICIES.  THE ABSTRACTION AND LINKING OF UNIFORM, STATE-BASED MORTALITY INFORMATION, CONSISTENT WITH THE NATIONAL VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM PROGRAM STANDARDS, WILL CONTINUE TO ASSIST PRACTITIONERS, RESEARCHERS, AND POLICY MAKERS IN UNDERSTANDING THE FACTORS ASSOCIATED WITH VIOLENT DEATHS IN UTAH.

COLLECTING VIOLENT DEATH INFORMATION IN TENNESSEE USING THE NATIONAL VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM. - THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT NEW STRATEGIES AND ENHANCE EXISTING STRATEGIES TO IMPROVE SURVEILLANCE OF VIOLENT DEATH IN TENNESSEE. WE PROPOSE TO IMPLEMENT A VIOLENT DEATH REVIEW SYSTEM TO IDENTIFY, ABSTRACT, AND ANALYZE VIOLENT DEATH THROUGH COLLABORATION WITH DIVISIONS WITHIN THE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND OUTSIDE AGENCIES.  THE DATA ELEMENTS REQUIRED FOR THIS PROJECT WILL BE IDENTIFIED AND ABSTRACTED FROM THE VARIOUS SOURCES, THEN ENTERED INTO THE NVDRS.  THE WORK DONE WILL NOT ONLY INFORM PREVENTION EFFORTS IN TENNESSEE, BUT WILL ALSO SUPPORT THE CDC'S EFFORT TO IMPROVE THE PLANNING, IMPLEMENTATION, AND EVALUATION OF VIOLENCE PREVENTION PROGRAMS.

RHODE ISLAND VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM - VIOLENCE IS A MAJOR PREVENTABLE PUBLIC HEALTH PROBLEM IN THE UNITED STATES AND RHODE ISLAND. THROUGH THIS FUNDING OPPORTUNITY, THE RHODE ISLAND VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM (RIVDRS) PLANS TO ENHANCE ITS SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM AND COLLABORATE WITH PARTNERS SO DATA CAN BE USED TO INFORM ACTION AND REDUCE THE BURDEN OF VIOLENT DEATHS IN THE STATE. RIVDRS INTENDS TO ACHIEVE FIVE MAIN OUTCOMES BY THE END OF THE PROJECT PERIOD. THE FIRST OUTCOME IS TO IMPROVE THE COMPLETENESS, TIMELINESS, AND QUALITY OF RIVDRS DATA (OUTCOME 1). INNOVATIVE STRATEGIES TO IMPROVE MORE TIMELY AVAILABILITY OF DATA AND COMPLETENESS OF VARIABLES, SUCH AS SEXUAL ORIENTATION AND GENDER IDENTITY, ARE DISCUSSED IN THE APPLICATION. RIVDRS PLANS TO ENSURE DIVERSITY OF ITS ADVISORY COMMITTEE AND COLLABORATE WITH COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO STRENGTHEN RELATIONSHIPS WITH KEY PARTNERS (OUTCOME 2). DATA WILL BE DISSEMINATED USING MULTIPLE METHODS TO ENSURE THE PUBLIC AND PARTNERS HAVE BOTH INCREASED ACCESS TO RIVDRS DATA (OUTCOME 3) AND INCREASED USE OF RIVDRS DATA TO INFORM VIOLENCE PREVENTION ACTIVITIES (OUTCOME 4). THE CREATION AND DISSEMINATION OF AN OPTIONAL DATA DASHBOARD IS PROPOSED. RIVDRS ALSO PLANS TO FURTHER INTEGRATE GIS MAPPING AND COMPLEMENTARY DATA SOURCES. THESE ACTIVITIES AIM TO INCREASE THE ABILITY TO DESCRIBE THE GEOGRAPHIC DISTRIBUTION OF VIOLENT DEATHS AND BETTER UNDERSTAND LINKAGES BETWEEN VIOLENT DEATH-RELATED HEALTH DISPARITIES IN RHODE ISLAND AND SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH (OUTCOME 5).

ADVANCING SURVEILLANCE OF VIOLENT DEATHS USING THE NEW JERSEY VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM - THE NEW JERSEY DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH, POPULATION HEALTH DIVISION, CENTER FOR HEALTH STATISTICS, HAS ESTABLISHED THE NEW JERSEY VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM THROUGH A COOPERATIVE AGREEMENT WITH THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION AS PART OF THE NATIONAL VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM. BY ESTABLISHING AND MAINTAINING COLLABORATIVE RELATIONSHIPS, THE GOAL OF THIS PROJECT IS TO LINK VITAL STATISTICS, MEDICAL EXAMINER, AND LAW ENFORCEMENT REPORTS TOGETHER INTO A SINGLE COMPREHENSIVE SOURCE FOR SURVEILLANCE DATA ON VIOLENT DEATHS IN NEW JERSEY. THIS SYSTEM WILL CONTINUE TO BE USED TO AID VIOLENCE PREVENTION AND REDUCTION EFFORTS IN THE STATE, WITH THE GOALS OF CREATING A CONTINUOUSLY IMPROVING VIOLENT DEATH SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM THAT CAN DISSEMINATE DATA TO PARTNERS AND STAKEHOLDERS AND SUPPORT THE IMPLEMENTATION OF VIOLENCE PREVENTION PLANS TO ULTIMATELY DECREASE THE INCIDENCE OF VIOLENT DEATHS. THIS PROJECT RELATES TO THE “HEALTHY PEOPLE 2030” OBJECTIVES OF VIOLENCE AND INJURY PREVENTION AND REDUCING ITS CONSEQUENCES.  THE MEASURES OF EFFECTIVENESS THAT ARE OUTLINED IN THE STRATEGIES AND ACTIVITIES ARE IN ALIGNMENT WITH THE STRATEGIC PRIORITIES OF THE NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL, DIVISION OF VIOLENCE PREVENTION MISSION TO “…PROVIDE LEADERSHIP AND BUILD BRIDGES ACROSS SECTORS TO USE DATA AND CONDUCT RESEARCH TO INFORM PREVENTION ACTIVITIES.”

THE TITLE OF THIS PROJECT IS THE MISSISSIPPI VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM, WHICH WILL SERVE AS THE LEADING SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM FOR VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING IN MISSISSIPPI. - THE MISSISSIPPI STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH (MSDH) PROPOSES THE ADVANCEMENT OF THE MISSISSIPPI VIOLENT DEATHS REPORTING SYSTEM (MS-VDRS) THROUGH THE “ADVANCING SURVEILLANCE OF VIOLENT DEATHS DEATH USING THE NATIONAL VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM (NVDRS)” GRANT OPPORTUNITY CDC-RFA-CE22-2201. THE MS-VDRS IS A CONTINUOUSLY IMPROVING STATEWIDE VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM WITH COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE OFFICE OF PREVENTIVE HEALTH AND HEALTH EQUITY, OFFICE OF HEALTH STATISTICS AND VITAL RECORDS, THE OFFICE OF HEALTH DATA AND RESEARCH, AND THE OFFICE AGAINST INTERPERSONAL VIOLENCE AT MSDH. A VIOLENT DEATH IS DEFINED AS A DEATH RESULTING FROM THE INTENTIONAL USE OF FORCE OR POWER (E.G., THREATS OR INTIMIDATION) AGAINST ONESELF, ANOTHER PERSON, OR AGAINST A GROUP OR COMMUNITY. WITH ONE OF THE HIGHEST HOMICIDE MORTALITY RATES IN THE NATION, AND WITH SIGNIFICANT RACIAL AND GEOGRAPHIC DISPARITIES IN VIOLENT DEATHS, THE MS-VDRS SEEKS TO ADVANCE STATEWIDE CAPACITY FOR ALL 82 COUNTIES TO SYSTEMATICALLY COLLECT INTEGRATED, HIGH QUALITY, AND COMPREHENSIVE SURVEILLANCE DATA ON ALL VIOLENT DEATHS, DISSEMINATE VIOLENT DEATH DATA TO IMPROVE THE EFFECTIVENESS OF VIOLENCE PREVENTION EFFORTS IMPLEMENTED BY ALL STATE, MUNICIPAL, AND COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS, AND CONTINUE TO BUILD AND LEVERAGE STRONG RELATIONSHIPS WITH KEY PARTNERS. MS-VDRS WILL BUILD CAPACITY FOR EPIDEMIOLOGIC SCIENCE AND GEOCODING TO CONDUCT LINKAGES TO DATA WITH INFORMATION ON SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH OR OTHER RELEVANT DATA.  THE USE OF A PUBLIC-FACING DATA DASHBOARD WILL PROMOTE DATA ACCESS AND DISSEMINATION EFFORTS. THE MS-VDRS OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVED COMPLETENESS, QUALITY, AND TIMELINESS OF VIOLENT DEATH SURVEILLANCE DATA, STRONGER RELATIONSHIPS AND INCREASED USE OF DATA KEY PARTNERS, AND INCREASED ABILITY TO DESCRIBE THE GEOGRAPHIC DISTRIBUTION OF VIOLENT DEATH AND UNDERSTAND THE SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH IN RELATION TO VIOLENT DEATH-RELATED HEALTH DISPARITIES.  THE MS-VDRS IS GUIDED BY AN ADVISORY COMMITTEE THAT HELPS COLLECT REQUIRED DATA AND PROVIDES INPUT ON THE QUALITY OF THE SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM. THE ADVISORY COMMITTEE INCLUDES PRIMARY MS-VDRS DATA PARTNERS SUCH AS LOCAL CORONERS/MEDICAL EXAMINERS (C/ME), LAW ENFORCEMENT (LE), AND THE MSDH OFFICE OF HEALTH STATISTICS AND VITAL RECORDS. TO ACCOMPLISH PROGRAM OUTCOMES, THE MS-VDRS WILL ADVANCE THE FOLLOWING OUTPUTS: A CONTINUOUSLY IMPROVING SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM THAT COLLECTS HIGH QUALITY AND COMPREHENSIVE INFORMATION ON VIOLENT DEATHS IN MISSISSIPPI IN A TIMELY MANNER THAT COMPLIES WITH CDC GUIDELINES; GEOCODING AND LINKAGE OF SOCIAL DETERMINANTS DATA; AND THE PRODUCTION AND/OR DISSEMINATION OF DATA THROUGH REPORTS, FACT SHEETS, PRESENTATIONS, POLICY BRIEFS, AND OTHER PRODUCTS THAT SUPPORT THE PREVENTION OF VIOLENT DEATHS IN MISSISSIPPI. MS-VDRS WILL CONTINUE TO PROVIDE CRITICAL INSIGHT INTO THE MAGNITUDE, TRENDS, AND FACTORS THAT MAY CONTRIBUTE TO VIOLENT DEATHS IN MISSISSIPPI.  THE PROGRAM’S OBJECTIVE IS TO ADVANCE THE PLANNING, SURVEILLANCE, AND KNOWLEDGE OF VIOLENCE PREVENTION TO IMPROVE DISPARITIES AND HEALTH OUTCOMES FOR THE CITIZENS OF MISSISSIPPI.

MINNESOTA VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM: PREVENTING VIOLENCE - THE INJURY AND VIOLENCE PREVENTION SECTION (IVPS) AT THE MINNESOTA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH (MDH) IS PREPARING AN APPLICATION FOR THE CDC NATIONAL VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM (NVDRS) GRANT. THIS WOULD CONTINUE THE WORK THAT MINNESOTA HAS BEEN DOING SINCE 2015 FOR NVDRS AND WOULD INCLUDE, AMONG OTHER ELEMENTS, DATA ON VICTIMS IN MINNESOTA WHO DIED BY VIOLENCE, THE PERPETRATOR, WEAPON USED, AND CIRCUMSTANCES INVOLVED.  THE PURPOSE OF NVDRS IS TO ASSIST STATE GOVERNMENTS IN UNDERSTANDING THE EXTENT OF VIOLENCE-RELATED DEATHS, IDENTIFYING RISK FACTORS, AND DEVELOPING AND EVALUATING VIOLENCE PREVENTION PROGRAM EFFORTS. IN COLLABORATION WITH PARTNERS, THE MDH WILL COLLECT STANDARD CDC DATA ELEMENTS ON ALL VIOLENT DEATHS IN THEIR TARGETED AREAS. THE DATA WILL THEN BE ENTERED INTO CDC-MANAGED WEB SYSTEM. DATA ELEMENTS WILL BE COLLECTED FROM THREE SOURCES: -	DEATH CERTIFICATES (DC), -	CORONER/MEDICAL EXAMINER (CME) REPORTS (INCLUDING TOXICOLOGY REPORTS), AND -	LAW ENFORCEMENT (LE) REPORTS. IN 2019, A RECORD-HIGH OF 984 PEOPLE DIED FROM SUICIDE OR HOMICIDE IN MINNESOTA. THIS WAS 45% HIGHER THAN A DECADE EARLIER. AVAILABLE STATISTICS FROM 2020 AND 2021 INDICATE OVER 1,000 DEATHS EACH YEAR IN MINNESOTA WILL MEET THE NVDRS INCLUSION CRITERIA. DESPITE THIS INCREASING TRENDS, MDH STAFF HAVE CONTINUED TO IMPROVE PROCESSES AND EFFICIENCIES SUCH THAT THE 2020 DATA YEAR FOR NVDRS HAD 78% OF CASES WITH LAW ENFORCEMENT CIRCUMSTANCES AND 90% OF CASES WITH MEDICAL EXAMINER/CORONER CIRCUMSTANCES CHECKED, BOTH THE HIGHEST TOTALS EVER ACHIEVED IN MINNESOTA.  OUTCOMES EXPECTED FROM CONTINUING THE MINNESOTA VDRS PROJECT INCLUDE, BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO, IMPROVED DATA ACCURACY AND COMPLETENESS OF NVDRS DATA, LAUNCH OF A DATA DASHBOARD FOR MINNESOTA VDRS, INCREASED NUMBER OF USERS OF MINNESOTA VDRS DATA, AND A REDUCTION IN SUICIDE AND HOMICIDE IN MINNESOTA, PARTICULARLY AMONG DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED POPULATIONS.  THROUGH A COMBINATION OF EXPERIENCED STAFF, A REVISED AND IMPROVED WORK PLAN, AND DEDICATION TO THIS IMPORTANT WORK, THE MINNESOTA VDRS TEAM IS LOOKING FORWARD TO ENHANCING THE QUALITY AND ACCURACY OF THE NVDRS SYSTEM THROUGH 2027.

IDAHO VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM GRANT APPLICATION - BVRHS WILL USE THE FUNDING FROM THIS GRANT OPPORTUNITY TO CONTINUE TO FUND THE IDAHO VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM (IDVDRS). THE IDVDRS CURRENTLY COLLECTS AND DISSEMINATES DATA ON VIOLENT DEATHS FROM THREE DIFFERENT SOURCES: IDAHO DEATH CERTIFICATES, IDAHO COUNTY CORONERS, AND LAW ENFORCEMENT.  THE DATA THAT COME FROM THE IDVDRS IS USED TO INFORM STAKEHOLDERS AND TO IMPROVE PLANNING, IMPLEMENTATION, AND EVALUATION OF VIOLENCE PREVENTION POLICIES AND PROGRAMS. THIS IS PRIMARILY EXECUTED USING THE IDVDRS DATA DASHBOARD LOCATED ON THE IDAHO DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND WELFARE’S GETHEALTHYIDAHO WEBSITE (HTTP://WWW.GETHEALTHY.DHW.IDAHO.GOV).  THIS PROJECT WILL HAVE MULTIPLE OUTCOMES OVER THE GRANT TIMELINE. THESE OUTCOMES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO: IMPROVING COMPLETENESS, TIMELINESS, AND QUALITY OF VIOLENT DEATH SURVEILLANCE DATA; IMPROVING RELATIONSHIPS WITH KEY PARTNERS, INCLUDING DATA PROVIDERS AND PROGRAM STAKEHOLDERS; INCREASE ACCESS TO NVDRS DATA BY THE PUBLIC AND PROGRAM PARTNERS; IMPROVEMENT BY PARTNERS IN HOW THEY INFORM THE DESIGN, INCREASE EFFECTIVENESS OF VIOLENCE PREVENTION EFFORTS IN IDAHO; DECREASED MORBIDITY AND MORTALITY DUE TO VIOLENCE; AND INCREASED USE OF INNOVATIVE METHODS OF UTILIZING IDVDRS DATA. IDVDRS WILL ALSO BE TAKING ADVANTAGE OF THE OPTIONAL DATA DASHBOARD FUNDING OPPORTUNITY AS A WAY TO EXPAND THE CURRENT IDVDRS DATA DASHBOARD.
ADVANCING SURVEILLANCE OF VIOLENT DEATHS  USING THE NATIONAL VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM (NVDRS) - 2022

ALABAMA VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM - TO CONTINUE TO IMPROVE THE NATIONAL VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM (NVDRS) IN ALABAMA, THE ALABAMA DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH WILL CONTINUE PARTNERING WITH THE ALABAMA CENTER FOR HEALTH STATISTICS, ALABAMA DEPARTMENT OF FORENSIC SCIENCES, JEFFERSON COUNTY CORONER/MEDICAL EXAMINER’S OFFICE, ALABAMA CORONER’S ASSOCIATION, AND THE ALABAMA LAW ENFORCEMENT AGENCY TO COLLECT DATA ON VIOLENT DEATHS IN THE STATE. DATA WILL INCLUDE DEATH CERTIFICATES, AUTOPSY AND TOXICOLOGY REPORTS, MEDICAL EXAMINER AND CORONER REPORTS, AND FIREARM AND POLICE REPORTS. THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION’S (CDC) WEB-BASED NVDRS WILL ALLOW FOR THE COLLECTION AND DISSEMINATION OF SURVEILLANCE DATA ON VIOLENT DEATHS WHICH, IN TURN, WILL PROVIDE A VIABLE OUTCOME OF IMPROVING THE PLANNING; IMPLEMENTATION; AND EVALUATION OF VIOLENCE PREVENTION PROGRAMS. OTHER PROGRAM OUTCOMES INCLUDE CREATING STRONGER RELATIONSHIPS WITH KEY PARTNERS WHILE ALSO RECRUITING NEW DATA PARTNERS. THIS ENSURES THAT QUALITY DATA IS OBTAINED AND INCREASES PUBLIC AND PARTNER ACCESS TO AVDRS DATA TO ASSIST IN INFORMING VIOLENCE PREVENTION ACTIVITIES AND POLICIES. THE PROGRAM WILL INCREASE AWARENESS AND UNDERSTANDING OF THE RELATIONSHIP OF SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH AND VIOLENT DEATH-RELATED HEALTH DISPARITIES. NVDRS WILL ALSO ALLOW THE STATE TO ANALYZE CHARACTERISTICS AND TRENDS OF VIOLENT DEATHS WHICH NO OTHER ENTITY IN THE STATE IS CURRENTLY ANALYZING. THE PROGRAM WILL CONTINUE TO TARGET ALL VIOLENT DEATHS IN THE STATE’S 67 COUNTIES WHICH OCCUR DURING THE PERFORMANCE PERIOD OF THE GRANT. THE GOALS FOR NVDRS WILL INCLUDE CREATING AND MAINTAINING A CONTINUALLY IMPROVING SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM THAT COLLECTS HIGH QUALITY AND COMPREHENSIVE VIOLENT DEATH INFORMATION IN A TIMELY MANNER THAT COMPLIES WITH CDC GUIDELINES; DISSEMINATING NVDRS DATA TO PARTNERS AND THE PUBLIC TO SUPPORT VIOLENCE PREVENTION; AND EXPLORING INNOVATIVE METHODS OF ACCESSING, REPORTING, AND SHARING DATA. STRATEGIES TO COMPLETE THESE GOALS WILL INCLUDE: IMPLEMENTING NVDRS, COLLECTING AND ABSTRACTING DATA REQUIRED BY NVDRS, ASSESSING THE CURRENT DEATH TOLL OF VIOLENCE IN ALABAMA USING DEATH CERTIFICATE INFORMATION AND ADDITIONAL DATA UPLOADED TO NVDRS TO SHOW HOW ALABAMA RATES COMPARE TO NATIONAL RATES, GENERATING AN ANNUAL REPORT FOR THE STATE USING DE-IDENTIFIED NVDRS DATA, AND EXPLORING INNOVATIVE METHODS OF ACCESSING, REPORTING, AND SHARING DATA TO INCLUDE VIOLENCE PREVENTION ADVOCACY GROUPS. THE SURVEILLANCE AND PREVENTION BRANCH WILL CONTINUE ITS ESTABLISHED PARTNERSHIPS THAT WILL BENEFIT NVDRS. THOSE PARTNERSHIPS ARE WITH THE ALABAMA CHILD DEATH REVIEW SYSTEM AND THE SUDDEN UNEXPLAINED DRUG OVERDOSE REPORTING SYSTEM. COLLABORATION WITH THESE TWO PROGRAMS WILL ASSIST IN EXPANDING THE USE OF NVDRS DATA.
ADVANCING SURVEILLANCE OF VIOLENT DEATHS  USING THE NATIONAL VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM (NVDRS) - 2022
ADVANCING SURVEILLANCE OF VIOLENT DEATHS  USING THE NATIONAL VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM (NVDRS) - 2022

NEW HAMPSHIRE'S ADVANCING SURVEILLANCE OF VIOLENT DEATHS USING THE NATIONAL VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM - APPLICANT NAME:  NH DEPT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES DESCRIPTIVE TITLE OF APPLICANT'S PROJECT:  NEW HAMPSHIRE’S ADVANCING SURVEILLANCE OF VIOLENT DEATHS USING THE NATIONAL VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM (NVDRS)  THE NEW HAMPSHIRE (NH) DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES (DHHS), INJURY PREVENTION PROGRAM (IPP), IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE NH DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE (DOJ), OFFICE OF THE CHIEF MEDICAL EXAMINER (OCME), INTENDS TO USE THE FULL AMOUNT ALLOWED, $196,896, FOR THE BASE APPLICATION TO CONTINUE THE NVDRS DATA COLLECTION. THIS BASE FUNDING WILL BE USED TO CONTINUE COLLECTION OF NH DEATHS RELATED TO SUICIDES, HOMICIDES, AND FIRE-ARE DEATHS OF ALL INTENTS. IN ADDITION TO THE BASE, NH DHHS WILL ALSO APPLY FOR $100,000 ALLOWED TO DEVELOP A DATA DASHBOARD USING NH-VDRS DATA. TO CREATE THE DATA DASHBOARD, THE IPP WILL COLLABORATE WITH THE NH BUREAU OF PUBLIC HEALTH STATISTICS AND INFORMATICS (BPHSI). THE BPHSI WILL HIRE A SYSTEMS DEVELOPMENT SPECIALIST TO WORK ON THE DASHBOARD PROJECT. SEE THE PROJECT NARRATIVE FOR MORE DETAILS.

WISCONSIN'S NVDRS APPLICATION - BASE AND SUPPLEMENT - WISCONSIN'S NATIONAL VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEMS (NVDRS) CDC-RFA-CE22-2201 NOTICE OF FUNDING OPPORTUNITY PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO MAINTAIN AND IMPROVE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE NATIONAL VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM IN WISCONSIN. THE WISCONSIN VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM (WI-VDRS) IS AN ONGOING STATEWIDE, COMPREHENSIVE, ACTIVE INJURY SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM THAT LINKS DATA ACROSS MULTIPLE SOURCES TO PROVIDE PUBLIC HEALTH SURVEILLANCE ON VIOLENCE RELATED INJURIES. IT GENERATES INFORMATION ON ALL VIOLENT DEATHS THAT IS DETAILED, USEFUL, AND TIMELY AT THE LOCAL, STATE, AND NATIONAL LEVELS. THESE DATA ARE AND WILL BE USED TO ASSESS THE EXTENT OF VIOLENT DEATHS IN WISCONSIN, TO IDENTIFY THE RELATIVE CONTRIBUTION OF DIFFERENT RISK FACTORS, AND TO INFORM PREVENTION PROGRAM AND PUBLIC POLICY DEVELOPMENT, IMPLEMENTATION AND EVALUATION. SINCE 2015, WISCONSIN HAS EXPERIENCED AN ANNUAL AVERAGE OF OVER 1,100 VIOLENT DEATHS, WITH MORE THAN THREE-QUARTERS OF THESE DEATHS CLASSIFIED AS SUICIDES. THE WI-VDRS PROGRAM SUPPORTS DATA COLLECTION ON ALL VIOLENT DEATHS ACROSS THE STATE. DATA IS ANALYZED AND FINDINGS ARE BROADLY DISSEMINATED THROUGH EXISTING AND EXPANDED CHANNELS. CASE-LEVEL DATA, WITHOUT PERSONAL IDENTIFIERS, WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE NATIONAL VDRS MAINTAINED BY THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION (CDC). THE WI-VDRS PROGRAM, IN THE BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SECTION OF THE WISCONSIN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH SERVICES, HAS, IN COLLABORATION WITH THE DIVISION OF PUBLIC HEALTH’S OFFICE OF HEALTH INFORMATICS (OHI), ESTABLISHED ITS ABILITY TO CONDUCT SURVEILLANCE OF DEATHS DUE TO VIOLENCE SINCE THE INCEPTION OF NATIONAL VIOLENT DEATH SURVEILLANCE IN THE EARLY 2000’S. THIS APPLICATION OUTLINES WI-VDRS’ PLANS TO CONTINUE THE COLLECTION, ANALYSES, AND DISSEMINATION OF VIOLENT DEATH DATA ACCORDING TO CDC’S GUIDELINES, AND DOCUMENTS OUR ABILITY TO DO SO THROUGH OUR LENGTH OF EXPERIENCE, PLANNING, AND FORMAL COLLABORATION ACROSS MULTIPLE PARTNERS. THE WI-VDRS PROGRAM IS A STATEWIDE PROGRAM AND IS ESTIMATED TO SERVE A POPULATION OF MORE THAN 5.8 MILLION PEOPLE, AS OF 2020.

OKLAHOMA VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM - THE OKLAHOMA VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM (OKVDRS) HAS BEEN MAINTAINED IN THE INJURY PREVENTION SERVICE OF THE OKLAHOMA STATE DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH (OSDH) SINCE 2004. DATA ARE COLLECTED ONGOING FROM DEATH CERTIFICATE DATA FROM THE OSDH CENTER FOR HEALTH STATISTICS (CHS), MEDICAL EXAMINER REPORTS FROM THE OFFICE OF THE CHIEF MEDICAL EXAMINER (OCME), AND LAW ENFORCEMENT RECORDS PROVIDED BY THE OKLAHOMA STATE BUREAU OF INVESTIGATION (OSBI). THE PURPOSE OF THE OKVDRS IS TO COLLECT AND DISSEMINATE ACCURATE, TIMELY, AND HIGH-QUALITY SURVEILLANCE DATA ON ALL VIOLENT DEATHS USING CDC GUIDELINES AND THE CDC WEB-BASED DATA ENTRY SYSTEM TO INFORM VIOLENCE PREVENTION EFFORTS AND TO ULTIMATELY REDUCE MORBIDITY AND MORTALITY RELATED TO VIOLENCE THROUGH DATA TO ACTION. OUTCOMES FOR THIS PROJECT INCLUDE: 1.	IMPROVED COMPLETENESS, TIMELINESS, AND QUALITY OF VIOLENT DEATH SURVEILLANCE DATA. 2.	STRONGER RELATIONSHIPS WITH KEY PARTNERS. 3.	INCREASED ACCESS TO NVDRS DATA BY THE PUBLIC AND PARTNERS TO INFORM THEIR VIOLENCE AND POSSIBLY INJURY PREVENTION ACTIVITIES. 4.	INCREASED USE OF VIOLENT DEATH SURVEILLANCE DATA BY PARTNERS TO INFORM VIOLENCE PREVENTION PROGRAMMATIC AND POLICY DECISIONS. 5.	INCREASED ABILITY TO DESCRIBE THE GEOGRAPHIC DISTRIBUTION OF VIOLENT DEATHS AND UNDERSTAND THE SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH IN RELATION TO VIOLENT DEATH-RELATED HEALTH DISPARITIES.

ADVANCING THE VIOLENT DEATH COLLECTION AND DATA DISSEMINATION USING THE NATIONAL VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM IN NEVADA. - THE NEVADA HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES (DHHS), NEVADA’S STATE VITAL RECORDS AUTHORITY, ALONG WITH LOCAL PARTNERS, PROPOSES TO COLLECT DATA ON ALL VIOLENT DEATHS THAT OCCUR DURING PERIOD OF PERFORMANCE (OPTION 1).  PARTICIPATION IN THE NATIONAL VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM (NVDRS) WILL SUPPORT A STRATEGIC COLLABORATION BETWEEN THE DHHS, THE COUNTY CMES AND THE VARIOUS LE AGENCIES OF NEVADA.  ALTHOUGH EACH AGENCY IS REQUIRED TO WORK WITH VARIOUS ASPECTS OF DEATHS RESULTING FROM VIOLENCE, THIS EFFORT WILL GALVANIZE EFFORTS TOWARD: INTERSTATE DATA SHARING, PUBLIC HEATH SURVEILLANCE OF VIOLENT DEATH TRENDS AND THE EPIDEMIOLOGY SUPPORT NECESSARY TO IDENTIFY FUTURE PREVENTION ACTIVITIES AND SUPPORT CURRENT PROGRAMS DESIGNED TO LOWER THE INCIDENTS OF VIOLENT DEATH IN NEVADA AND THE UNITED STATES. IF FUNDED, THE NEVADA NVDRS (NVVDRS) WILL BE A CENTRALIZED SYSTEM IN NEVADA THAT COLLECTS AND COMBINES STATEWIDE VIOLENT DEATH INFORMATION AND DISSEMINATES IT AT THE COUNTY, STATE AND NATIONAL LEVELS.  THE COLLECTION AND DISSEMINATION OF COMPREHENSIVE INFORMATION AND THE ABILITY TO DETECT VIOLENT DEATH TRENDS TIMELY IS CRITICAL TO SUPPORT VIOLENCE PREVENTION EFFORTS IN NEVADA. THIS FUNDING WILL MAINTAIN THE INFRASTRUCTURE NECESSARY TO COLLECT ALL REQUIRED DATA ELEMENTS AND ASSOCIATED REPORTS AS DESCRIBED IN THE FUNDING OPPORTUNITY ANNOUNCEMENT (FOA). THE CONTINUATION OF NVVDRS AND ITS NETWORK OF DATA PROVIDERS WILL BE THE ONLY STATEWIDE SYSTEM LINKING CMES, LE AND PUBLIC HEALTH ELECTRONICALLY TO SUPPORT THE CDC’S NVDRS.  ALTHOUGH THE NUMBER OF VIOLENT DEATHS IN NEVADA MAY SEEM LOW AT FIRST GLANCE, ITS RATE OF VIOLENT DEATHS, SUCH AS SUICIDES, EXCEEDS NATIONAL NUMBERS IN MANY INSTANCES.  ADDITIONALLY, ITS GEOGRAPHIC SIZE, POPULATION DISBURSEMENT, CENTERS OF TOURISM, AND RESIDENT'S LIFESTYLES MAKE NEVADA UNIQUE.  THE SOCIOECONOMIC DIVERSITY AND THE TYPES OF VIOLENCE ASSOCIATED WITH THIS ENVIRONMENT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO CDC EFFORTS TO PERFORM SURVEILLANCE AND SUPPORT PREVENTION ACTIVITIES NATIONALLY.

MA VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM (MAVDRS) - THE NATIONAL VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM (NVDRS) IS A CDC INITIATIVE DESIGNED TO PROVIDE COMPREHENSIVE DATA FROM MULTIPLE SOURCES ON THE INCIDENCE AND CIRCUMSTANCES OF VIOLENT DEATHS. THESE DATA WILL BE USED FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF EFFECTIVE PREVENTION PROGRAMS. THE MASSACHUSETTS DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH (MDPH) WAS ONE OF THE FIRST SIX STATES FUNDED TO BEGIN COLLECTING DATA IN 2003 FOR NVDRS. MDPH SEEKS FUNDING UNDER OPPORTUNITY NUMBER CDC-RFA-CE22-2201 TO CONTINUE THE COLLECTION OF VIOLENT DEATH INFORMATION USING THE NVDRS FOR THE YEARS 2023-2027 UNDER THIS INITIATIVE. THE MASSACHUSETTS VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM (MAVDRS) IS A SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM FOR VIOLENT DEATHS OCCURRING IN MASSACHUSETTS AND UTILIZES DATA FROM THE REGISTRY OF VITAL RECORDS AND STATISTICS, THE OFFICE OF THE CHIEF MEDICAL EXAMINER, THE MASSACHUSETTS STATE POLICE, AND THE BOSTON POLICE DEPARTMENT TO MONITOR, CHARACTERIZE, AND UNDERSTAND THE CIRCUMSTANCES LEADING UP TO THESE DEATHS. VIOLENT DEATHS INCLUDE HOMICIDES, SUICIDES, DEATHS OF UNDETERMINED INTENT, LEGAL INTERVENTION DEATHS AND ALL FIREARM FATALITIES. THESE DEATHS ARE A MAJOR PUBLIC HEALTH PROBLEM IN MASSACHUSETTS AND THROUGHOUT THE UNITED STATES. IN 2019, MAVDRS IDENTIFIED OVER 880 VIOLENT DEATHS IN MASSACHUSETTS. ALMOST THREE-QUARTERS (72%) OF THESE DEATHS WERE SUICIDES, 17% WERE DUE TO HOMICIDE, AND 10% WERE DEATHS OF UNDETERMINED INTENT. MAVDRS PROVIDES DETAILED INFORMATION ON THESE DEATHS THROUGH THE MAINTENANCE OF A MULTI-SOURCE, LINKED, CASE-LEVEL DATABASE, WHICH CAN PROVIDE MORE IN-DEPTH INFORMATION THAN ANY OF THE INDIVIDUAL DATA SOURCES ALONE. MAVDRS WILL BE ENTERED INTO THE WEB-BASED SYSTEM MAINTAINED BY CDC IN A MANNER STANDARDIZED ACROSS ALL NVDRS STATES AND CONSISTENT WITH CDC GUIDELINES FOR THE PROJECT. THE FIRST PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS THE CONTINUED COLLECTION OF ACCURATE, TIMELY, HIGH QUALITY AND COMPREHENSIVE SURVEILLANCE DATA ON VIOLENT DEATHS OCCURRING IN MASSACHUSETTS IN COMPLIANCE WITH CDC GUIDELINES. COLLABORATIVE AGREEMENTS BETWEEN MDPH AND THE DATA PROVIDERS, ESTABLISHED FOR MAVDRS IMPLEMENTATION, DEMONSTRATE BROAD-BASED COMMITMENT FROM PUBLIC HEALTH AND PUBLIC SAFETY TO UNDERSTAND AND PREVENT VIOLENT DEATHS BETTER. MAVDRS WILL ALSO ENHANCE ITS SYSTEM BY IMPROVING THE QUALITY AND COMPLETENESS OF ITS DATA. BROAD DISSEMINATION OF FINDINGS FROM THE SYSTEM IS THE SECOND PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT. THE FOUR KEY OUTCOMES OF THIS PROJECT ARE IMPROVED COMPLETENESS, QUALITY AND TIMELINESS OF VIOLENT DEATH SURVEILLANCE DATA, A STRONG WORKING RELATIONSHIP WITH KEY PARTNERS AS EVIDENCED BY CONTINUED OR EXPANDED PARTICIPATION IN MAVDRS PROJECT AND INCREASED ACCESS AND USE OF VIOLENT DEATH SURVEILLANCE DATA BY PARTNERS WORKING TO PREVENT VIOLENCE AND THE PUBLIC AND INCREASED ABILITY TO DESCRIBE THE GEOGRAPHIC DISTRIBUTION OF VIOLENT DEATH AND UNDERSTAND THE SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH IN RELATION TO VIOLENT DEATH-RELATED HEALTH DISPARITIES. MAVDRS IS A COLLABORATIVE PROJECT AND ITS SUCCESS IN IMPLEMENTATION, MAINTENANCE AND ENHANCEMENT IS THE RESULT OF THE ONGOING COMMITMENT OF OUR STATE, OTHER NVDRS- FUNDED STATES, CDC AND OTHER NATIONAL PARTNERS.

MICHIGAN VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM - AS OF 2021, MICHIGAN HAS OVER 2,800 DEATHS EACH YEAR THAT MEET THE DEFINITIONS FOR INCLUSION IN THE NATIONAL VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM (NVDRS), AN INCREASE OF 20% SINCE 2015. WHILE THE STATE HAS PARTICIPATED IN THE NVDRS SINCE 2010, WE STILL NEED TO KNOW MORE ABOUT THE CHARACTERISTICS OF THESE INCIDENTS, THEIR VICTIMS, AND THE PRECEDING AND PRECIPITATING CIRCUMSTANCES TO THESE DEATHS--INFORMATION THAT CAN HELP IMPROVE PREVENTION PRACTICE AND POLICY DEVELOPMENT.      THE MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES (MDHHS), INJURY & VIOLENCE PREVENTION SECTION IS PROPOSING TO CONTINUE BRINGING TOGETHER DATA FROM MULTIPLE LOCAL AND STATE LEVEL DATA SOURCES TO CREATE A REPOSITORY OF DETAILED INFORMATION ON THESE VIOLENT DEATH INCIDENTS. THIS WILL ALLOW DETAILED EXAMINATION OF WHAT IS KILLING PEOPLE IN THE GREAT LAKES STATE AND PROVIDE STOREHOUSE OF KNOWLEDGE WITH WHICH TO INFORM DATA-DRIVEN PROGRAMMING AND POLICY DECISION MAKING AT THE STATE AND LOCAL LEVEL. SINCE MDHHS IS PROPOSING TO CONTINUE STATEWIDE DATA COLLECTION, THE MICHIGAN VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM (MIVDRS) WILL CONTINUE TO BE A COMPREHENSIVE PUBLIC HEALTH SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM OF ALL DEATHS DUE TO VIOLENT MEANS OCCURRING IN THE STATE OF MICHIGAN. DATA IS COLLECTED FROM DEATH CERTIFICATES, LAW ENFORCEMENT (LE) RECORDS AND MEDICAL EXAMINER (ME) CASE FILES FOR ALL INCIDENTS OF HOMICIDE, SUICIDE, UNDETERMINED MANNER DEATHS INVOLVING TRAUMA OR POISONING, AND UNINTENTIONAL FIREARM-RELATED DEATHS.      MICHIGAN IS NOT AN EASY STATE IN WHICH TO UNDERTAKE THIS TYPE OF SYSTEM. THERE IS NOT A STATE ME OFFICE OR CENTRAL REPOSITORY FOR ME DATA; THE STATE’S 83 COUNTIES ARE SERVED BY OVER 50 CHIEF MES. SOME LE CASE DATA CAN BE OBTAINED BY FROM THE MICHIGAN STATE POLICE (MSP)--FILES ON CASES INVESTIGATED BY THAT AGENCY, SOME OF THE CASE FILES FROM LOCAL AGENCIES CURRENTLY USING THE CENTRALIZED ONLINE CASE MANAGEMENT SYSTEM OFFERED BY MSP FOR USE BY LOCAL LE AGENCIES (CURRENTLY BEING USED BY ~100 AGENCIES IN 12 COUNTIES), AND MINIMAL INFORMATION FROM THE MSP'S MICHIGAN INCIDENT CRIME REPORT DATABASE (INFORMATION SUBMITTED TO THE NATIONAL INCIDENT CRIME REPORTING SYSTEM). FOR THE MOST PART, LE CASE FILES FOR ABSTRACTION NEED TO BE ACQUIRED BY CONTACTING INDIVIDUAL LE AGENCIES, OF WHICH THERE ARE OVER 600 IN THE STATE. CURRENTLY, MUCH OF THE ME AND LE DATA COLLECTION NEEDS TO BE DONE BY MANUAL ABSTRACTION FROM HARD COPY CASE FILES OR ELECTRONIC DATA FILES, WHICH NEED TO BE ACQUIRED BY CONTACTING INDIVIDUAL ME OFFICES OR LE AGENCIES.      IT IS IMPORTANT THAT SURVEILLANCE DATA BE “BROUGHT TO LIFE” AND DISSEMINATED TO A WIDE RANGE OF END-USERS IN WAYS THAT ARE USEFUL TO THEM. AT LEAST THREE DISSEMINATION PRODUCTS WILL BE DEVELOPED AND USED EACH PROJECT YEAR. THE MIVDRS PROGRAM IS ALSO CURRENTLY PART OF A PILOT PROGRAM FUNDED BY THE JOYCE FOUNDATION TO DEVELOP A PUBLIC FACING DATA DASHBOARD USING THE MIVDRS DATA.      CAREFUL ATTENTION WILL BE PAID TO ASSURING DATA QUALITY AND AN EFFECTIVE, EFFICIENT SYSTEM. WORKING WITH MEMBERS OF CDC'S NVDRS TEAM, THE MIVDRS PROGRAM WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A DETAILED EVALUATION PLAN WITHIN THE FIRST 6 MONTHS OF GRANT FUNDING. THIS PLAN WILL THEN BE USED OVER THE REMAINING GRANT PERIOD TO ASSURE AN EFFICIENT SYSTEM AND HIGH QUALITY DATA.

BUILDING A SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM FOR VIOLENT DEATHS IN THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA - THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA (DC) IS A 68 SQUARE MILE JURISDICTION NESTLED BETWEEN THE STATES OF MARYLAND AND VIRGINIA. THE DISTRICT IS THE NATION’S CAPITAL, SERVES AS THE HOME OF THE UNITED STATES FEDERAL GOVERNMENT AND MORE THAN 160 FOREIGN EMBASSIES, AND IS HOME TO A RESIDENT POPULATION OF APPROXIMATELY 700,000 PEOPLE. DUE TO THE LARGE FEDERAL WORKFORCE AND VISITORS FROM AROUND THE WORLD, THE POPULATION OF THE DISTRICT ON ANY GIVEN DAY IS APPROXIMATELY 1.5 MILLION TO 2 MILLION PEOPLE. THE POPULATION OF THE DISTRICT IS RACIALLY DIVERSE WITH 45% AFRICAN AMERICAN, 42% CAUCASIAN, 4% ASIAN, AND 7% OTHER. APPROXIMATELY 9% OF THE POPULATION IS OF HISPANIC ORIGIN, AND 13% IS FOREIGN BORN. THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA HAS MADE GREAT STRIDES IN REDUCING MORTALITY FROM VIOLENT DEATHS, PARTICULARLY HOMICIDES, WHICH ARE DOWN FROM HISTORIC AND NATION LEADING HIGHS IN THE 1990S TO A MUCH MORE MANAGEABLE NUMBER NOW. HOWEVER, DEEP DISPARITIES ACROSS RACIAL AND WARD (GEOGRAPHICAL LINES) PERSIST. DESPITE DRAMATIC REDUCTIONS IN VIOLENT MORTALITY, THERE STILL EXISTS A SALIENT OPPORTUNITY TO FURTHER REDUCE DEATHS, IN ADDITION TO AN URGENT NEED TO ADDRESS THE RACIAL/GEOSPATIAL DISPARITIES IN DEATHS. TRADITIONALLY, VIOLENT DEATH AND INJURY HAS BEEN LOOKED AT STRICTLY AS A LEGAL/LAW ENFORCEMENT ISSUE. WITH THIS SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM, THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA INTENDS TO TRULY TREAT VIOLENT DEATH AS A PUBLIC HEALTH PROBLEM, AND BRING A NEW APPROACH AND RESOURCES TO FIRST UNDERSTAND THE PROBLEM, THEN INFORM AND EXECUTE EFFECTIVE PREVENTION STRATEGIES. IN DEVELOPING AN EFFICIENT AND COMPREHENSIVE SYSTEM TO TRACK AND DESCRIBE VIOLENT DEATHS, THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH WILL CONTINUE TO PROVIDE NVDRS DATA THAT CAN BE USED TO INFORM PREVENTION EFFORTS AND REDUCE THE NUMBER OF DEATHS. THIS SYSTEM WILL GATHER VITAL INFORMATION ON THE CIRCUMSTANCES SURROUNDING VIOLENT CRIME, INCLUDING SUSPECT, VICTIM AND WEAPON DATA, WHICH CAN BE USED TO EXAMINE THE CONTEXT AND PREDICTORS OF VIOLENT CRIME WITHIN THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, AND ARM PREVENTION AND LAW ENFORCEMENT GROUPS WITH TIMELY AND COMPREHENSIVE DATA TO REDUCE VIOLENT DEATHS. THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH WILL MAINTAIN ITS ROBUST AND COMPREHENSIVE SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM CAPABLE OF CAPTURING DATA ON VIOLENT DEATHS IN A TIMELY AND EFFECTIVE MANNER. THE RESOURCES FROM THIS PROJECT WILL STRENGTHEN EXISTING RELATIONSHIPS WITH OUR PUBLIC HEALTH AND LEGAL PARTNERS, AS WELL AS TRIGGER NEW COLLABORATIONS BASED ON THE DISSEMINATION OF THIS VITAL DATA. WITH REGULAR REPORTING, WITH INPUT AND REQUESTS FROM OUR STAKEHOLDERS, EFFECTIVE DATA THAT CAN INFORM VIOLENCE PREVENTION AND MITIGATION ACTIVITIES WILL BE AVAILABLE FOR THE FIRST TIME.

FLORIDA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH, COMMUNITY HEALTH PROMOTION - GRANT APPLICATION FOR THE ADVANCING SURVEILLANCE OF VIOLENT DEATHS USING THE NVDRS FUNDING ANNOUNCEMENT CDC-RFA-CE22-2201. - VIOLENCE AND INJURY ARE A SERIOUS PUBLIC HEALTH ISSUE IN FLORIDA. IN 2020, MORE THAN 5,000 PEOPLE IN FLORIDA DIED AS A RESULT OF A VIOLENT INJURY. THE MAJORITY OF THESE DEATHS WERE SUICIDE (N=3,195, 63.9%) FOLLOWED BY HOMICIDE (N=1,583, 31.7%), DEATHS DUE TO UNDETERMINED INTENT (N=917, 3.0%), LEGAL INTERVENTION (N=227,1.2%), AND FIREARM-RELATED ACCIDENTS (N=153, 0.3%), RESPECTIVELY. THE TOP FIVE FLORIDA COUNTIES REPORTING VIOLENT DEATHS IN 2020 WERE MIAMI-DADE (N=535), BROWARD (N=388), DUVAL (N=348), HILLSBOROUGH (N=324), AND PALM BEACH (N=279). THIS DISTRIBUTION VARIES SLIGHTLY WHEN LOOKING SPECIFICALLY AT VIOLENT DEATHS DUE TO SUICIDE OR HOMICIDE. FLORIDA IS THE THIRD MOST POPULOUS STATE IN THE UNITED STATES, WITH MORE THAN 21 MILLION RESIDENTS IN 67 DIVERSE COUNTIES WITH VARYING PUBLIC HEALTH NEEDS. THIS TOTAL DOES NOT INCLUDE THE MORE THAN 110 MILLION TOURISTS WHO VISIT FLORIDA EVERY YEAR. NEARLY HALF OF FLORIDA COUNTIES ARE RURAL AREAS WITH LOCAL RISK FACTORS THAT PRESENT UNIQUE CHALLENGES FOR VIOLENCE AND INJURY PREVENTION.  THE NATIONAL VIOLENT DEATH REPORTING SYSTEM (NVDRS) ENABLES FLORIDA TO SUPPORT STATEWIDE VIOLENCE PREVENTION EFFORTS BY: 1) ENHANCING VIOLENT DEATH DATA SURVEILLANCE THROUGH COLLABORATION WITH THE FDOH BUREAU OF VITAL STATISTICS, MEDICAL EXAMINER (ME) DISTRICT OFFICES, AND LE AGENCIES; 2) IDENTIFYING COUNTIES WITH THE HIGHEST NUMBER AND/OR RATES OF VIOLENT DEATHS THROUGH DATA SURVEILLANCE; AND 3) SUPPORTING LOCAL LE AGENCIES, ME DISTRICT OFFICES, STAKEHOLDERS AND THE PUBLIC THROUGH DATA DISSEMINATION. THE PURPOSE OF FLVDRS IS TO COLLECT AND DISSEMINATE ACCURATE, TIMELY, AND COMPREHENSIVE SURVEILLANCE DATA ON ALL VIOLENT DEATHS IN OUR TARGET AREA IN FLORIDA USING CDC GUIDELINES AND THE CDC WEB-BASED DATA ENTRY SYSTEM (SAMS) TO INCREASE VIOLENCE PREVENTION EFFORTS AND REDUCE MORBIDITY AND MORTALITY RELATED TO VIOLENCE.

KENTUCKY VIOLENCE AND INJURY PREVENTION PROGRAM - KENTUCKY IS DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED BY HIGH UNINTENTIONAL INJURY, TRAFFIC FATALITY AND CHILD MALTREATMENT RATES AND RISK FACTORS (RFS) LIKE POVERTY AND SUBSTANCE MISUSE THAT INCREASE SUSCEPTIBILITY TO INJURY AND DEATH. THE KY INJURY PREVENTION AND RESEARCH CENTER (KIPRC) IS A BONA FIDE AGENT FOR THE KY DEPT. FOR PUBLIC HEALTH AND AN INDEPENDENT RESEARCH CENTER AT THE UNIVERSITY OF KY. THE PURPOSE OF KY?S APPLICATION IS TO DECREASE INJURY MORBIDITY AND MORTALITY RATES THAT SUPPORTS HEALTHY PEOPLE 2030, BY BUILDING ON EXISTING SURVEILLANCE, IMPLEMENTATION, EVALUATION, AND DISSEMINATION STRATEGIES AND LEVERAGED RESOURCE CAPACITY DEVELOPED DURING PAST CDC CORE GRANTS (RFA CE-16-1602, SUPCOVID19 AND CE11-1101) WITH OUR MULTISECTORAL PARTNERS (E.G., INJURY COMMUNITY IMPLEMENTATION GROUP) TO INFORM PUBLIC HEALTH ACTION FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF NEW AND ENHANCED EXISTING IVP STRATEGIES THAT WILL FOCUS ON DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED POPULATIONS (DAPS) WITHIN THE NOTICE OF FUNDING OPPORTUNITY PRIORITY FOCUS AREAS (PFAS): ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCE, TRAUMATIC BRAIN INJURY, TRANSPORTATION SAFETY, AND LOCAL CONCERN AREA OF FALLS.STRATEGY 1) KY WILL CONDUCT ROBUST DATA SURVEILLANCE BY CONTINUING TO IDENTIFY EXISTING AND NEW DATA SOURCES FOR SURVEILLANCE OF INJURIES ACROSS PFAS THROUGH THE UTILIZATION OF EXISTING, PARTNER-MAINTAINED, AND PUBLICLY AVAILABLE DATA SOURCES. DATA WILL BE ANALYZED TO MONITOR EMERGING INJURY TOPICS AND PFAS AND TO PRODUCE ANNUAL SURVEILLANCE PFA PRODUCTS, INJURY INDICATOR REPORTS, AND SPECIAL EMPHASIS REPORTS. WE WILL TRANSLATE AND DISSEMINATE SURVEILLANCE PRODUCTS TO STAKEHOLDERS, DAP REPRESENTATIVES AND OTHER PARTNERS THROUGH DIRECT CONTACT AND KIPRC COMMUNICATION CHANNELS. KY WILL PARTICIPATE IN A NATIONAL IVP SURVEILLANCE LEARNING COMMUNITY AND INCORPORATE BEST PRACTICES TO ENHANCE SURVEILLANCE PRODUCTS AND QUALITY. SURVEILLANCE OUTPUTS WILL BE USED TO SUPPORT THE IVP PROGRAMMING AND COLLABORATIONS DESCRIBED BELOW AS WELL AS T O IDENTIFY EMERGING INJURY TOPICS AND DAPS.STRATEGY 2) KY WILL IDENTIFY AND FORM STRATEGIC COLLABORATIONS WITH MULTIDISCIPLINARY PARTNERS TO STRENGTHEN STATE AND COMMUNITY IVP AND PFA ACTIVITIES, SUCH AS IMPLEMENTATION OF OUR STATE IVP PLAN. THROUGH A PARTNERSHIP CAPACITY INVENTORY, WE WILL DETERMINE CAPACITY AND NEEDS OF TRADITIONAL AND NON-TRADITIONAL IVP PARTNERS TO ADDRESS PFAS. KY WILL UTILIZE PARTNERSHIPS TO TRANSLATE ACTIONABLE DATA FROM SURVEILLANCE, ASSESSMENT AND EVALUATION TO HIGH-IMPACT, NEW AND EXISTING EVIDENCE-BASED AND -INFORMED ACTIONABLE STRATEGIES TO ADDRESS PFAS. EXAMPLES INCLUDE OUR EXISTING CONNECT PROGRAM, DIAS-BASED PAHT EDUCATION, CHECKPOINTS? TEEN DRIVER SAFETY PROGRAM, TRAFFIC SOBRIETY CHECKPOINTS, LOCAL HEROES, AND GATEKEEPER TRAINING PLUS NEW ACTIVITIES - E.G. SEEK-PARENT QUESTIONNAIRE-R, NEED ASSESSMENTS FOR FALLS AND TBI, PURPLE STAR PROGRAM, DRUG RECOGNITION EXPERT PROGRAM AND BINGOCIZE?. KY WILL ALSO PARTICIPATE IN PEER-TO-PEER LEARNING VIA REGIONAL AND NATIONAL NETWORKING GROUPS.STRATEGY 3) KY WILL WORK TO ASSESS, EVALUATE, AND IDENTIFY THE NEEDS, RFS AND PROTECTIVE FACTORS (PFS), AND APPROPRIATE EVIDENCE-INFORMED STRATEGIES TO IMPROVE OUTCOMES IN DAPS ACROSS THE PFAS IN COLLABORATION WITH MULTISECTORAL PARTNERS AND DAP REPRESENTATIVES. WE WILL USE ASSESSMENTS RESULTS, SURVEILLANCE DATA, LITERATURE, AND PARTNERSHIPS TO IDENTIFY GAPS IN IVP ACTIVITIES AND OPPORTUNITIES TO INFORM STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS AND FUTURE MULTISECTOR COLLABORATIONS, TO SUPPORT THE IMPLEMENTATION AND REFINEMENT OF TARGETED IVP STRATEGIES AND EVALUATION, TO STRENGTHEN SURVEILLANCE DATA USE, AND TO INFORM BEST AVAILABLE EVIDENCE IVP.IT IS THROUGH THESE STRATEGIES AND ACTIVITIES THAT KY WILL INFORM PUBLIC HEALTH ACTION FOR IVP; AND KY WILL WORK TO REDUCE PFA INJURIES AND RFS, AND TO INCREASE PFS ACROSS DAPS.

ALASKA CORE INJURY PREVENTION PROGRAM (AK CORE SIPP) - IN EFFORTS TO SUPPORT AND MANAGE BROAD PUBLIC HEALTH PROGRAMS, THE STATE OF ALASKA HAS WORKED TO ADOPT PROGRESSIVE PUBLIC HEALTH FRAMEWORKS WHICH HELP CONNECT PROGRAMS WITH RESOURCES, BUILD CAPACITY, AND INCREASE PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY. THROUGH MULTI-SECTORAL EFFORTS, ALASKA HAS WIDELY ADOPTED A SHARED RISK AND PROTECTIVE FACTORS FRAMEWORK (SRPF) WHICH SEEKS TO APPROACH PUBLIC HEALTH CHALLENGES FROM A HIGHLY COORDINATED SERVICE-BASED APPROACH THAT IS DATA-DRIVEN AND IN ACCORDANCE WITH CDC GUIDELINES.  ALASKA?S CORE SIPP PROGRAM WILL INCREASE DATA COLLECTION, MANAGEMENT, AND ANALYSIS CAPACITY THAT WILL LEAD TO IMPACTFUL PUBLIC HEALTH ACTIONS. THE FOCUS OF THE PROJECT RESPONDS TO A PROMINENT PUBLIC HEALTH CHALLENGE: INTENTIONAL AND UNINTENTIONAL INJURY AND MORBIDITY WHICH HAS BEEN WELL DOCUMENTED BY THE CDC TO BE TIED TO ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCES (ACES), TRAUMATIC BRAIN INJURIES (TBI), AND TRANSPORTATION-RELATED INJURIES, AND WHICH COMBINED PROVIDE CONTEXT FOR ADULT BEHAVIORS LEADING TO INJURY.  EXISTING INJURY STATISTICS FURTHER HIGHLIGHT THE NEED FOR IMPROVED DATA COLLECTION AND ANALYSIS TO UNDERSTAND WHERE, WHEN, WHY AND HOW INJURY IS OCCURRING. ALASKA IS RANKED 7TH AMONG STATES WITH THE HIGHEST RATES OF UNINTENTIONAL INJURY IN THE UNITED STATES. INJURY IS THE THIRD-LEADING CAUSE OF DEATH IN ALASKA, BEHIND ONLY CANCER AND HEART DISEASE. IT IS ALSO AMONG THE LEADING CAUSES OF HOSPITALIZATION.1 THE IMPACTS TO ALASKANS EXTEND BEYOND HEALTH TO FINANCIAL BURDEN. THE TOTAL AMOUNT BILLED TO ALASKA RESIDENTS FOR ACUTE CARE RECEIVED FOR SERIOUS TRANSPORTATION-RELATED INJURY MORE THAN DOUBLED BETWEEN 2012 AND 2016, FROM $40 MILLION TO $91 MILLION.2 FURTHERMORE, TRAUMATIC BRAIN INJURIES (TBI) MADE UP NEARLY ONE IN FIVE (19.2%) OF ALL REPORTED INJURIES RESULTING IN A HOSPITAL STAY OVER 24 HOURS FROM 2012 TO 2016.3 IT IS ALSO ESTIMATED THAT 40.6% OF ALASKAN ADULTS RECEIVING MEDICAID, DO SO AS A RESULT OF ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCES. THAT REPRESENTS NEARLY $350 MILLION IN ANNUAL COSTS.4 THROUGH DATA-DRIVEN PREVENTION AND PUBLIC HEALTH ACTIONS, THESE GRANT FUNDED ACTIVITIES WILL PROVIDE RESOURCES TO SUPPORT TARGETED PUBLIC HEALTH IMPROVEMENT EFFORTS.  THE ALASKA DIVISION OF PUBLIC HEALTH, SECTION OF CHRONIC DISEASE PREVENTION AND HEALTH PROMOTION, INJURY PREVENTION UNIT IN PARTNERSHIP WITH TRIBAL, NON-PROFIT, UNIVERSITY, AND OTHER CROSS SECTOR PARTNERS WILL, IN THE COURSE OF THIS FIVE YEAR PROJECT, INCREASE KNOWLEDGE AND UTILIZATION OF EMERGING DATA SOURCES FOR INJURY SURVEILLANCE AND ROBUST DATA PRACTICES, STRENGTHEN COMMUNITIES BY INCREASING PROTECTIVE FACTORS AND REDUCING RISK FACTORS FOR INJURIES USING BEST AVAILABLE EVIDENCE, AND SUSTAIN INJURY PREVENTION PUBLIC HEALTH ACTIONS. THE PURPOSE OF THIS?PROJECT?IS TO?STRENGTHEN ALASKA?S INJURY PREVENTION PROGRAMS AND POLICIES AND DEMONSTRATE IMPACT?ON SHARED RISK?AND PROTECTIVE?FACTORS FOR ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCES, TRANSPORTATION SAFETY, AND TBI?BY INCREASING SOURCES OF DATA, STANDARDIZING REGULAR, RECURRING DATA ANALYSIS AND DISSEMINATION; IMPROVING INTERCONNECTIVITY OF DATA ACROSS SOURCES; AND USING DATA TO EXPAND PARTNERSHIPS, INCREASE STAKEHOLDER ENGAGEMENT, AND DRIVE DECISION-MAKING TOWARD PUBLIC HEALTH ACTION, INCLUDING PROGRESS TOWARD EQUITY THROUGH A FOCUS ON DISPROPORTIONATELY-AFFECTED POPULATIONS AND COMMUNITIES.? INCREASED EFFORTS TO PREVENT INJURIES ARE NECESSARY IN ORDER TO DECREASE HEALTH CARE COSTS, INJURY MORTALITY, AND MORBIDITY ASSOCIATED WITH ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCES, TRANSPORTATION SAFETY AND TRAUMATIC BRAIN INJURIES. AS NOTED BY THE ALASKA INJURY FACTS REPORT, ?A PUBLIC HEALTH APPROACH TO INJURY PREVENTION SEEKS TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH, SAFETY, AND WELLBEING OF A POPULATION BY ADDRESSING INDIVIDUAL, SOCIAL, ENVIRONMENTAL, AND SOCIETAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH. THIS PROCESS INVOLVES IDENTIFYING AND REDUCING RISK FACTORS WHILE ALSO IDENTIFYING AND LEVERAGING PROTECTIVE FACTORS TO ADVANCE OVERALL HEALTH.?

OHIO CORE SIPP BASE AND ENHANCED STRATEGIES FOR DATA TO ACTION - THE APPROACH PROPOSED FOR THE BASE COMPONENT PLACES AN EMPHASIS ON UTILIZING DATA AND SURVEILLANCE TO ACHIEVE PUBLIC HEALTH IMPACT; WORKING WITH PARTNERS TO IMPLEMENT  EVIDENCE-BASED PROGRAMS AND STRATEGIES THAT REDUCE RISK FACTORS AND INCREASE PROTECTIVE FACTORS; AND EVALUATING AND ASSESSING EFFORTS TO IMPROVE HEALTH OUTCOMES IN EACH FOCUS AREA. FOCUS AREAS INCLUDE: ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCES; TRANSPORTATION SAFETY; TRAUMATIC BRAIN INJURY AND SITE SPECIFIC- YOUTH SUICIDE: ENHANCED SYSTEMS OF CARE.  ODH ALSO PROPOSES TO IMPLEMENT AN ENHANCED EVALUATION AND IMPLEMENTATION COMPONENT FROM THE PREVENTING ACES: LEVERAGING THE BEST AVAILABLE EVIDENCE TECHNICAL PACKAGE. THE STRATEGY IS INTERVENE TO LESSEN IMMEDIATE AND LONG-TERM HARMS THROUGH THE ENHANCED PRIMARY CARE APPROACH. THE IMPLEMENTATION PROJECT WILL BE SUBJECT TO A DUALLY FOCUSED EVALUATION PLAN OF 1) EXPLORING IF THE PROVIDER APPROACH TO DISCUSSIONS ON SAFE STORAGE AND ADOLESCENT SUICIDE CAN HAVE SIGNIFICANT IMPACTS ON HOW PATIENTS AND FAMILIES ENGAGE IN THE CONVERSATION, ACCEPTANCE OF ANTICIPATORY GUIDANCE, AND 2) IDENTIFYING CORRELATIONS AMONG ADOLESCENTS WHO SCREEN WITH AN ELEVATED SCORE FOR DEPRESSION/SUICIDAL IDEATION AND THOSE WHO DO NOT THROUGH THE LENS OF INCREASING REFERRALS.

OREGON CORE STATE INJURY PREVENTION PROGRAM (CORE SIPP) - BASIC: THE OHA, PHD, IVPP PROPOSES INITIATIVES TO ENHANCE SPECIFIC PROTECTIVE FACTORS: COMMUNITY RESILIENCE, SAFE AND HEALTHY ENVIRONMENTS, CONNECTEDNESS, AND HEALTHY SOCIAL NORMS. IN ADDITION TO THE REQUIRED FOCUS ON ACES, TBI AND TS, IT PROPOSES A PROJECT OF LOCAL SIGNIFICANCE USING 18.5% THE BASE BUDGET TO EXPANSION OF OUR SURVEILLANCE CAPACITY FOR OLDER ADULT FALLS, ADULT TBI AND ALCOHOL AS AN UNINTENTIONAL INJURY RISK FACTOR. MID-TERM OUTCOMES- INCREASED: 1) ABILITY TO IDENTIFY AND RESPOND TO EMERGING INJURY THREATS; 2) CAPACITY TO STRENGTHEN COMMUNITIES BY INCREASING PROTECTIVE FACTORS FOR INJURIES USING BEST AVAILABLE EVIDENCE; 3) CAPACITY TO STRENGTHEN COMMUNITIES BY REDUCING RISK FACTORS FOR INJURIES USING BEST AVAILABLE EVIDENCE; 4) SUSTAINED INJURY PREVENTION PUBLIC HEALTH ACTIONS SUPPORTED BY BEST AVAILABLE EVIDENCE; 5)  SYSTEMS AND ORGANIZATIONAL CAPACITY FOR ENGAGING COMMUNITIES THAT ARE DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED BY RISK FACTORS, AND 2) CAPACITY TO LINK DATASETS FOR PROVIDING CONTEXT AND INFORMATION AROUND SRPF FOR UNINTENTIONAL FALLS, TRANSPORTATION, AND TBI INJURIES. LONG-TERM OUTCOMES- REDUCED AND SUSTAINED 1) INJURY MORBIDITY AND MORTALITY ASSOCIATED WITH ACES, TS, AND TBI; AND 2) RISK FACTORS FOR ACES, TS AND TBI; INCREASED AND SUSTAINED PROTECTIVE FACTORS FOR ACES, TS AND TBI; AND 3) SUSTAINED ADVANCEMENT AND IMPROVEMENT IN INJURY PREVENTION PRACTICES AND OUTCOMES. ENHANCED:  EVALUATION WILL BUILD UPON THE LIMITED EVALUATION CURRENTLY UNDERWAY OF IVPP?S CDC 2020 CORE SVIPP-FUNDED MINI-GRANT INITIATIVE. IVPP WILL PARTNER WITH GRANT RECIPIENT ORGANIZATIONS TO CO-DESIGN, IMPLEMENT, AND PUBLISH A ROBUST EVALUATION OF THE OUTCOMES OF A LOW-BARRIER, COMMUNITY-INFORMED LGBTQ+ MINI-GRANT PROJECT THAT SUPPORTED SOCIAL COHESION AND INDIVIDUAL RESILIENCE DURING COVID-19. AN EHR INFORMATION STUDY WILL EXPLORE FEASIBILITY AND UTILITY OF A NEW DATA SOURCE?SOGI DATA IN MEDICAID HEALTH PLAN DATA SYSTEMS?TO IDENTIFY THE IMPACT OF INJURY AND  VIOLENCE IN OREGON?S LGBTQ+ POPULATION AND INFORM FUTURE PROVISION OF EVIDENCE-BASED MITIGATION INTERVENTIONS THROUGH HEALTH SYSTEMS. A SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM CAPACITY BUILDING PROJECT WILL IDENTIFY GAPS IN CURRENT INFORMATION SOURCES, SURVEY QUESTIONS, AND SURVEY METHODOLOGY RELATED TO SOGI VARIABLES IN PUBLIC HEALTH SURVEILLANCE SYSTEMS, CONDUCT AN ENVIRONMENTAL SCAN TO IDENTIFY RESOURCES FOR IMPROVEMENT, AND PRODUCE RECOMMENDATIONS FOR IMPROVEMENT. SHORT-TERM OUTCOMES: INCREASED: 1) ABILITY TO DESCRIBE THE ROLE OF CDC 2020 CORE SVIPP COVID-19 SUPPLEMENTAL FUNDING IN SUPPORTING IMPLEMENTATION EFFORTS (THE LGBTQ+ MINI-GRANT PROJECT); 2) ABILITY TO SYSTEMATICALLY APPLY EVALUATION PRINCIPLES AND METHODS, 3) UTILIZATION OF EVALUATION RESULTS; 4) UNDERSTANDING OF THE PROJECT?S EFFECT ON SYSTEM AND/OR BEHAVIOR CHANGE; 5) SUSTAINABLE, RECIPROCAL AND MULTI-SECTOR PARTNERSHIPS TO ADDRESS INJURY PREVENTION AMONG DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED POPULATIONS; 6) INCREASED USE OF NOVEL ANALYTIC DATA SCIENCE METHODS (USING HEALTH SYSTEM DATA ON SOGI VARIABLES, ENHANCING SURVEY SYSTEM CAPACITY) TO ADVANCE UNDERSTANDING OF INJURY IN DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED POPULATIONS (LGBTQ+ OREGONIANS) WITHIN THE CONTEXT OF STATEWIDE INJURY BURDEN MID-TERM OUTCOMES: 1) INCREASED RECIPIENT ABILITY TO SHOW CONTRIBUTIONS OF INTERVENTION(S) ON INTERMEDIATE AND LONG-TERM OUTCOMES; 2) STRENGTHEN THE EVIDENCE BASE FOR INJURY PREVENTION; 3) INCREASED RECIPIENT ABILITY TO APPROPRIATELY ADAPT IMPLEMENTATION PRACTICES TO ALIGN WITH LOCAL CONTEXTS; 4) INCREASED SYSTEMS AND ORGANIZATIONAL CAPACITY FOR ENGAGING COMMUNITIES THAT ARE DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED BY RISK FACTORS; 5) CONTRIBUTE INNOVATIVE SURVEILLANCE METHODS TO ADVANCE INJURY EPIDEMIOLOGY; 6) IMPROVED UNDERSTANDING OF THE IMPACT OF PREVENTION ON INJURY INCIDENCE; 7) INCREASED CAPACITY OF OREGON'S INJURY SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM TO IDENTIFY SRPF, ACES, AND INJURY OUTCOMES AMONG DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED POPULATIONS

VIRGINIA CORE STATE INJURY PREVENTION  PROGRAM (SIPP) BASE - PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARYTHE VIRGINIA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH (VDH) INJURY AND VIOLENCE PREVENTION PROGRAM (IVPP) RECOGNIZES THAT UNINTENTIONAL AND INTENTIONAL INJURIES, HOSPITALIZATIONS, AND DEATH CONTINUE TO IMPACT INDIVIDUALS, FAMILIES, AND COMMUNITIES ON AN EMOTIONAL, PHYSICAL, AND FINANCIAL LEVEL IN VIRGINIA. MANY INJURIES AND EVENTS OF VIOLENCE CAN OCCUR MULTIPLE TIMES AND IN DIFFERENT FORMS FOR INDIVIDUALS ACROSS THEIR LIFESPAN, AND OFTEN HAVE THE SHARED RISK AND PROTECTIVE FACTORS. THE GOOD NEWS, INJURIES AND VIOLENCE ARE LARGELY CONSIDERED PREDICTABLE AND PREVENTABLE. SOCIO-ECOLOGICAL INTERVENTIONS AT THE INDIVIDUAL, RELATIONSHIP, COMMUNITY, AND SOCIETAL LEVEL CAN HELP VIRGINIA BETTER UNDERSTAND RISK AND THE LEVEL OF PROTECTION THAT PERSONS HAVE THAT REDUCE LIKELIHOOD FOR INJURIES AND VIOLENCE.THE CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION (CDC) NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL CORE STATE INJURY PREVENTION PROGRAM (CSIPP) CDC-RFA-CE21-2101 BASE FUNDING IS SUPPORTING VDH IVPP TO 1) STRENGTHEN ITS IVP PROGRAMS AND POLICIES, AND 2) DEMONSTRATE THE IMPACT OF A DECREASE IN RISK FACTORS AS IT RELATES TO FOUR CSIPP TOPIC AREAS: TRANSPORTATION SAFETY-RELATED INJURIES (TSRI), TRAUMATIC BRAIN INJURY (TBI), ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCES (ACES), AND SUICIDE. WORK WILL SUPPORT THE IDENTIFICATION AND RESPONSE TO RISK OF INJURIES AND DEATH THROUGH DATA-DRIVEN PUBLIC HEALTH ACTION FROM A SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH, CONTINUOUS QUALITY IMPROVEMENT (CQI), AND HEALTH EQUITY LENS; AND AN INCREASE IN PROTECTIVE FACTORS AND DECREASE IN RISK FACTORS USING THE BEST AVAILABLE EVIDENCE FOR INJURIES AND DEATH IN THE CSIPP TOPIC AREAS. THIS IS ACHIEVED BY 1) ENGAGING IN ROBUST STATE-BASED DATA AND SURVEILLANCE; 2) STRENGTHENING STRATEGIC COLLABORATIONS AND PARTNERSHIPS; AND 3) CONDUCTING ASSESSMENT AND EVALUATION, FOCUSING ON PRIORITY POPULATIONS FURTHER DEFINED IN THE APPLICATION: TSRI: CHILDREN AGED 0-9 YEARS, WITH A FOCUS ON HISPANIC/LATINX FAMIL IES IN HENRICO COUNTY AND THE CITY OF ALEXANDRIA; TBI: BLACK YOUTH AGED 10-19 YEARS STATEWIDE, WITH A FOCUS ON HENRICO COUNTY AND CITIES OF RICHMOND, NORFOLK, PORTSMOUTH, ROANOKE, LYNCHBURG, PETERSBURG, AND CHESAPEAKE; ACES: PRE- AND POSTNATAL POPULATION; AND SUICIDE: BLACK YOUTH AGED 10-19 YEARS STATEWIDE. SHORT TERM AND MID-TERM OUTCOMES FOR THIS COLLABORATIVE AND MULTIDISCIPLINARY INITIATIVE INCLUDE:? INCREASED RECIPIENT ABILITY TO IDENTIFY AND RESPOND TO EMERGING INJURY THREATS.? INCREASED RECIPIENT CAPACITY TO STRENGTHEN COMMUNITIES BY INCREASING PROTECTIVE FACTORS FOR INJURIES USING BEST AVAILABLE EVIDENCE.? INCREASED RECIPIENT CAPACITY TO STRENGTHEN COMMUNITIES BY REDUCING RISK FACTORS FOR INJURIES USING BEST AVAILABLE EVIDENCE.? SUSTAIN RECIPIENT INJURY PREVENTION PUBLIC HEALTH ACTIONS SUPPORTED BY BEST AVAILABLE EVIDENCE.TAKING AN APPROACH OF ROBUST DATA COLLECTION AND EVALUATION TO DRIVE PUBLIC HEALTH AND EMPOWER STRATEGIC PARTNERS THROUGH A HEALTH EQUITY LENS TO ADDRESS SHARED RISK AND PROTECTIVE FACTORS WILL ENSURE THAT COLLECTIVE IMPACT IS MET AND VIRGINIANS WILL EXPERIENCE INJURY AND VIOLENCE FREE LIVING.

NEW MEXICO CORE STATE INJURY PREVENTION PROGRAM (NM CORE SIPP) - INJURY IS A SERIOUS PUBLIC HEALTH PROBLEM AND A MAJOR CAUSE OF MORTALITY AND MORBIDITY IN NEW MEXICO (NM). NM RANKED SECOND IN THE NATION FOR ALL INJURY DEATHS IN 2019. ACCORDING TO CDC?S WISQARS, NM HAD A 1.76 GREATER AGE-ADJUSTED RATE FOR FATAL MOTOR VEHICLE INJURIES; AND 1.7 GREATER AGE-ADJUSTED RATE FOR FATAL TRAUMATIC BRAIN INJURIES THAN NATIONALLY IN 2019. DATA FROM THE NATIONAL SURVEY OF CHILD HEALTH SHOW THAT ABOUT 1 IN 4 (25.6%) NEW MEXICAN CHILDREN HAVE EXPERIENCED AT LEAST 2 CHILDHOOD ADVERSE EXPERIENCES (ACES) IN 2018-2019, WHICH IS SIGNIFICANTLY HIGHER THAN 18% OF CHILDREN NATIONALLY WHO EXPERIENCE AT LEAST 2 ACES. INJURY PREVENTION EFFORTS MUST ACCOUNT FOR THE STRIKINGLY DIFFERENT RACIAL/ETHNIC COMPOSITION IN NM COMPARED TO THE UNITED STATES. OF NM?S 2,102,656 RESIDENTS IN 2019, 1,035,766 (49%) WERE IDENTIFIED AS HISPANIC; 791,431 (38%) AS NON-HISPANIC WHITE; 190,798 (9%) AS AMERICAN INDIAN/ALASKA NATIVE; 47,642 (2%) AS BLACK/AFRICAN AMERICAN; AND 37,020 (2%) AS ASIAN OR PACIFIC ISLANDER. NM'S AMERICAN INDIAN POPULATION IS COMPOSED OF A PART OF THE NAVAJO NATION, 19 PUEBLOS, THE JICARILLA AND MESCALERO APACHE TRIBES, AND THOSE LIVING ELSEWHERE THAN THE TRIBAL AND PUEBLO LANDS.THE ANALYSIS OF INJURY DATA FOR NM LED TO THE IDENTIFICATION OF AMERICAN INDIANS AND MALES AS THE DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED POPULATIONS THAT WILL BE THE FOCUS OF THE PROJECT. MOTOR VEHICLE DEATHS IN NM WERE ABOUT THREE TIMES GREATER IN MALES (27.4 DEATHS PER 100,000 RESIDENTS) THAN FEMALES (10.2 DEATHS PER 100,000 RESIDENTS); AND ABOUT FIVE TIMES GREATER FOR NON-HISPANIC AMERICAN INDIAN/ALASKAN NATIVE (54.9 DEATHS PER 100,000 RESIDENTS) COMPARED TO NON-HISPANIC WHITES (11.3 DEATHS PER 100,000 RESIDENTS) DURING 2019.ABOUT A 1.5 TIMES GREATER PERCENTAGE (IT?S SIMPLER) OF AMERICAN INDIAN/ALASKAN NATIVES (33.3%) ADULTS REPORTED EXPERIENCING FOUR OR MORE ACES COMPARED TO NON-HISPANIC WHITES (22.0%) AND HISPANIC (23.7%) ADULTS IN NM.THE AGE-ADJUSTED RATE FOR FATAL TRAUMATIC BRAIN INJURIES (TBIS) IN NM WAS  ABOUT THREE TIMES GREATER FOR MALES (44.9 DEATHS PER 100,000 RESIDENTS) THAN FEMALES (14.1 DEATHS PER 100,000); AND ABOUT 1.25 GREATER FOR AMERICAN INDIAN/ALASKAN NATIVE 43.3 DEATHS PER 100,000 RESIDENTS) COMPARED TO NON-HISPANIC WHITES (36.7 DEATHS PER 100,000 RESIDENTS) DURING 2019.THE NEW MEXICO DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH (NMDOH) IS SEEKING FINANCIAL SUPPORT IN THE ANNUAL AMOUNT OF $250,000.00 TO IMPROVE PUBLIC HEALTH INFRASTRUCTURE, DATA AND PARTNERSHIPS TO MORE EFFECTIVELY IDENTIFY AND RESPOND TO INJURY THREATS WITH DATA DRIVEN, EVIDENCE-BASED PUBLIC HEALTH ACTIONS. THIS FUNDING WILL BE USED TO INCREASE THE CAPACITY OF NMDOH AND PARTNERS TO IMPLEMENT STRATEGIES  THAT INTEGRATE THE BEST AVAILABLE EVIDENCE AND DATA AND COMMUNITY INPUT ON NEEDS AND ASSETS, INTO A SHARED RISK AND PROTECTIVE FACTORS FRAMEWORK, WHICH WILL BE RIGOROUSLY EVALUATED ACROSS THE 5-YEAR FUNDING PERIOD. AS PART OF THIS EFFORT, IN YEAR ONE, NMDOH PLANS TO LEAD A COLLABORATIVE STRATEGIC PLANNING PROCESS  THAT WILL RESULT IN REENERGIZED EXISTING PARTNERSHIPS AND CREATION OF NEW ONES, IMPROVED DATA COLLECTION AND USE, DISSEMINATION OF INJURY DATA AND ADOPTION OF PROGRAM BEST PRACTICES, ALONG WITH A 5-YEAR INJURY PREVENTION STRATEGIC PLAN FOR THE STATE. YEARS TWO AND THREE OF THE PROJECT PERIOD WILL CONSIST MAINLY OF EVALUATION AND QUALITY IMPROVEMENT PROCESSES TO ASSESSES AND REFINE THE WORK PRODUCED DURING YEAR ONE, IMPROVED DATA QUALITY AND USE, AND INCREASED PUBLIC HEALTH ACTION ADDRESSING THE NEEDS OF IDENTIFIED PRIORITY POPULATIONS THROUGH IMPLEMENTATION OF STRATEGIC PLAN STRATEGIES. IN THE LONG-TERM NM WILL EXPERIENCE A REDUCTION IN INJURY MORBIDITY AND MORTALITY IN THE PRIORITY POPULATIONS, AND SUSTAINED PARTNERSHIPS WITH INFORMED PARTNERS.PARTICIPATING NMDOH STAFF HAVE EXPERTISE IN USING DATA FOR PUBLIC HEALTH PREVENTION, COALITION-BUILDING AND LEADERSHIP, STRATEGIC PLANNING AND PROGRAM EVALUATION.
