SPOKANE PREVAYLS (PREVENTING VIOLENCE AFFECTING YOUNG LIVES IN SPOKANE) - RESIDENTS OF SPOKANE COUNTY IN EASTERN WASHINGTON BEAR A DISPROPORTIONATE BURDEN OF THE MANY FORMS OF VIOLENCE. THE RATE OF DOMESTIC VIOLENCE CALLS TO LAW ENFORCEMENT IN THE COUNTY IS NEARLY TWICE THE STATE LEVEL, AND THE TREND HAS ONLY WORSENED OVER TIME. NEARLY HALF (45%) OF SPOKANE?S YOUTH REPORTED EXPERIENCING VIOLENCE. IN RESPONSE TO A 2017 NEEDS ASSESSMENT, THE SPOKANE REGIONAL DOMESTIC VIOLENCE COALITION (SRDVC)?A LONGSTANDING, MULTISECTOR COALITION OF FUNDERS, SERVICE PROVIDERS, CRIMINAL JUSTICE, HEALTH AND EDUCATION SYSTEMS, AND CITIZENS?LAUNCHED A COMMUNITY AWARENESS CAMPAIGN TO RAISE AWARENESS ABOUT VIOLENCE ACROSS AN ARRAY OF COMMUNITY PARTNERS AND OFFER PRACTICAL ACTION STEPS FOR STAKEHOLDERS. THE COALITION COMPLETED A FIVE-YEAR STRATEGIC PLAN IN JANUARY 2021. SRDVC AND PARTNERS PROPOSE TO ADDRESS MULTIPLE FORMS OF VIOLENCE IMPACTING ADOLESCENTS AND YOUNG ADULTS, PARTICULARLY IN SPOKANE?S OVERBURDENED WEST CENTRAL COMMUNITY, BY:?CREATING A SYSTEM TO REFER YOUTH ENCOUNTERING JUVENILE COURT WHO ARE AT INCREASED RISK OF VIOLENCE TO COMMUNITY-BASED PREVENTION PROGRAMS AND LAUNCHING THE GREEN DOT PROGRAM IN THE HIGH SCHOOL SERVING THE WEST CENTRAL NEIGHBORHOOD IN ORDER TO INCREASE IMPLEMENTATION OF EVIDENCE-BASED AND PROMISING PROGRAMS IN COMMUNITY-BASED SETTINGS, INCREASE KNOWLEDGE OF DV AND RISK AND PROTECTIVE FACTORS AMONG PARTICIPATING YOUTH, AND DECREASE VIOLENT ACTIVITIES AMONG PARTICIPATING YOUTH.?IMPLEMENTING A POSITIVE SOCIAL NORMS CAMPAIGN THROUGH THE EXPANSION OF AN EXISTING COMMUNITY EDUCATION CAMPAIGN IN ORDER TO INCREASE AWARENESS, ACCOUNTABILITY, AND ACTION FOR DV PREVENTION AND INTERVENTION AMONG THOSE EXPOSED TO THE CAMPAIGN; AND HEALTHY AND POSITIVE SOCIAL NORMS THAT PROTECT AGAINST YOUTH VIOLENCE.?ENHANCE STRATEGIC COLLABORATION AROUND SRDVC?S FIVE-YEAR STRATEGIC PLAN TO INCREASE THE COALITION?S CAPACITY TO PREVENT YOUTH VIOLENCE AND EXPAND STRATEGIC PLAN ACTIVITIES TO INCLUDE ADDRESSING YOUTH VIOLENCE.?EVALUATE THE QU ANTITY AND QUALITY OF EFFORT AND IMPACT OF STRATEGIES, PARTICULARLY FOCUSING ON RACIAL INEQUITIES, TO INCREASE EVALUATION AND TRANSLATION, AND ACCESS TO AND TRACKING OF DATA.

SAFE, EQUITABLE AND THRIVING YOUTH AND COMMUNITIES - COMMUNITY SAFETY AND YOUTH VIOLENCE WERE IDENTIFIED AS TOP HEALTH ISSUES FOR LINN COUNTY AND CEDAR RAPIDS, IOWA BETWEEN THE YEARS OF 2015 AND 2019. A GRASSROOTS MOVEMENT, THE SAFE, EQUITABLE, AND THRIVING TASKFORCE, RESPONDED TO THE DEATH OF A YOUNG TEEN IN 2015, AND PUBLISHED A REPORT OUTLINING FACTORS CONTRIBUTING TO YOUTH VIOLENCE IN CEDAR RAPIDS. IN THE 2018 LINN COUNTY COMMUNITY HEALTH ASSESSMENT, COMMUNITY SAFETY EMERGED AS A TOP HEALTH ISSUE, AND WAS PRIORITIZED AS ONE OF THE THREE TOP HEALTH ISSUES FOR THE COMMUNITY TO ADDRESS IN ORDER TO ACHIEVE A VISION FOR HEALTH. MUCH LIKE THE REST OF THE NATION, IN CEDAR RAPIDS AND LINN COUNTY, BLACK YOUTH AGES 14-24 ARE DISPROPORTIONATELY AFFECTED BY YOUTH VIOLENCE. RACIAL INEQUITIES ACROSS EDUCATIONAL ATTAINMENT, INCOME, EMPLOYMENT, AND NEIGHBORHOOD POVERTY CONTRIBUTE TO THE DISPROPORTIONAL RATES OF YOUTH VIOLENCE. IOWA RANKS 2ND HIGHEST IN THE UNITED STATES IN BLACK HOMICIDES AT A RATE OF 35.56 PER 100,000. IN CEDAR RAPIDS, BLACK, MALE, YOUTH ARE VICTIMIZED BY GUN VIOLENCE AT A RATE 48.9 TIMES THAT OF THEIR WHITE PEERS. FOR THAT REASON, BLACK YOUTH ARE THE PRIMARY POPULATION OF FOCUS FOR THE SAFE, EQUITABLE AND THRIVING YOUTH AND COMMUNITIES PROJECT. THE SAFE, EQUITABLE AND THRIVING YOUTH AND COMMUNITIES PROJECT BUILDS ON CURRENT VIOLENCE PREVENTION AND COMMUNITY CARE COORDINATION INITIATIVES WITHIN CEDAR RAPIDS AND LINN COUNTY IOWA TO ADDRESS RACISM AND YOUTH VIOLENCE AS A PUBLIC HEALTH CRISIS. KEY COMPONENTS OF THE PROJECT INCLUDE FOCUSING ON TWO SOCIETAL LEVEL PREVENTION STRATEGIES, IN COMBINATION WITH A STRATEGY TO MAINTAIN INDIVIDUAL AND INTERPERSONAL LEVEL PREVENTION, WHILE FOCUSING ON ADDRESSING SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH AND HEALTH INEQUITIES TO REDUCE FACTORS THAT CONTRIBUTE TO YOUTH VIOLENCE. THE PROJECT BUILDS UPON STRONG COLLABORATIONS BETWEEN COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS WITH A SHARED VISION FOR HEALTH. ALL THREE STRATEGIES ARE EVIDENCE-BASED PRACTICES THAT REDUCE YOUTH VIOLENCE PERPET RATION AND/OR VICTIMIZATION OR REDUCE RISK FACTORS OR INCREASE PROTECTIVE FACTORS FOR YOUTH VIOLENCE. THE FIRST OF TWO SOCIETAL LEVEL PREVENTION STRATEGIES UTILIZES THE EVIDENCE-BASED PUBLIC HEALTH MODEL GROUP VIOLENCE INTERVENTION TO CREATE PROTECTIVE ENVIRONMENTS BY PERFORMING STREET OUTREACH AND CHANGE COMMUNITY NORMS ABOUT VIOLENCE. GROUP VIOLENCE INTERVENTION IS A MODEL WHICH USES A COMBINATION OF FOCUSED DETERRENCE AND COMPREHENSIVE GUN VIOLENCE REDUCTION STRATEGIES. THE SECOND SOCIETAL LEVEL PREVENTION STRATEGY FOCUSES ON IMPLEMENTING PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT AND PUBLIC EDUCATION CAMPAIGNS TO PROMOTE SOCIAL NORMS THAT PROTECT AGAINST VIOLENCE AND ADVERSITY. THIS STRATEGY BUILDS COMMUNITY CONNECTEDNESS, COHESION, AND COMMUNITY RESILIENCY TO INCREASE PROTECTIVE FACTORS OF VIOLENCE.  THE THIRD STRATEGY PROVIDES INDIVIDUAL AND INTERPERSONAL EVIDENCE-BASED PREVENTION TO AT-RISK YOUTH AND FAMILIES TO LESSEN IMMEDIATE AND LONG-TERM HARMS OF TRAUMA SUCH AS VIOLENCE EXPOSURES AND PREVENT FUTURE RISK OF PERPETRATION AND VICTIMIZATION OF VIOLENCE. THE INTENDED OUTCOMES OF ALL THREE STRATEGIES IMPLEMENTED TOGETHER ARE DECREASES IN ACCEPTABILITY OF USING GUNS TO RESOLVE DISPUTES, NUMBER OF SHOTS FIRED, WEAPONS (GUN) CHARGES FOR YOUTH, VIOLENT CRIME RATE, FIREARM-RELATED DEATHS, AND YOUTH HOMICIDE. ADDITIONALLY, INCREASES IN UTILIZATION OF COMMUNITY SERVICES AMONG AT-RISK POPULATION, STABILITY OF FAMILIES AND INDIVIDUALS, NORMATIVE BELIEFS THAT VIOLENCE IS UNACCEPTABLE, COMMUNITY ENGAGEMENT AND CONNECTEDNESS, AWARENESS OF THE IMPACT OF SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH AND RACIAL INEQUITY ON VIOLENCE, AND THE PERCENTAGE OF CEDAR RAPIDS CITIZENS REPORTING AN OVERALL FEELING OF SAFETY ARE EXPECTED AS A RESULT OF THIS PROJECT. THE SAFE, EQUITABLE AND THRIVING YOUTH AND COMMUNITIES PROJECT INCORPORATES COMPREHENSIVE EVALUATION AND PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT PLAN TO ENSURE PROCESS AND OUTCOME EVALUATION IS IMPLEMENTED TO MONITOR PROGRESS TOWARD EXPECTED OUTCOM

MULTNOMAH COUNTY PREVAYL - PURPOSE: THE PURPOSE OF THE MULTNOMAH COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT?S (MCHD?S) PROPOSED PREVAYL PROJECT IS TO ADDRESS MULTIPLE FORMS OF VIOLENCE IMPACTING ADOLESCENTS AND YOUNG ADULTS IN MULTNOMAH COUNTY BY EMPOWERING YOUTH, BUILDING CAPACITY OF SUPPORTIVE ADULTS, ENGAGING MULTI-SECTOR STAKEHOLDERS, INCREASING SOCIAL COHESION, AND RAISING PUBLIC AWARENESS OF VIOLENCE?S ROOTS IN STRUCTURAL RACISM AND ASSOCIATED SOCIAL NORMS. THE PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON YOUTH IN THE ENTIRETY OF MULTNOMAH COUNTY, ADDRESSING THE LINKED CONDITIONS OF HIGHER RATES OF VIOLENT CRIME, POVERTY, AND INCOME INEQUALITY, COMPARED TO THE STATE OF OREGON. THE PROJECT WILL EMPHASIZE FOCUS ON NEIGHBORHOODS WITH MORE CONCENTRATED VIOLENT CRIME, WHICH ARE DISPROPORTIONATELY HOME TO BIPOC YOUTH.PROJECT SUMMARY: MCHD?S COMMUNITY VIOLENCE PREVENTION PROGRAM (CVPP) WILL WORK WITH THE EXISTING MULTI-SECTOR COMMUNITY ADVISORY BOARD (CAB) AND YOUTH ADVISORY BOARD (YAB) TO IMPLEMENT CRIME PREVENTION THROUGH ENVIRONMENTAL DESIGN (CPTED) AS A COMMUNITY-LEVEL VIOLENCE PREVENTION STRATEGY AND PRIDE, PREVENTION, PEACE (PPP) AS A SOCIETAL-LEVEL STRATEGY. MCHD, THE CAB, YAB, AND OTHER COUNTY AND COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS WILL UPDATE AND ENHANCE THE COUNTY?S COMPREHENSIVE TEEN DATING VIOLENCE AND YOUTH VIOLENCE PREVENTION PLAN WITH KEY FOCUS ON COMMUNITY/SOCIETAL LEVELS; ELEVATING THE INTERSECTION BETWEEN VIOLENCE, SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH, AND RACIAL INEQUITY; SUSTAINABILITY; AND ALIGNING WITH STATE PRIORITIES AND PLANS. MCHD WILL CONDUCT A PROCESS AND OUTCOME EVALUATION MEASURING THE EXTENT TO WHICH MCHD AND PARTNERS 1) INCREASE IMPLEMENTATION, REACH, IMPACT, AND SUSTAINABILITY OF CPTED AND PPP; 2) INCREASE AWARENESS, COLLABORATION, COORDINATION, AND COMMITMENT WITHIN MULTI-SECTOR COALITIONS TO UNDERSTAND THE CAUSES AND BUILD CAPACITY TO PREVENT MULTIPLE FORMS OF VIOLENCE; 3) ENHANCE LOCAL VIOLENCE PREVENTION PLANS AND ALIGN WITH OREGON?S STATE-LEVEL VIOLENCE PREVENTION PRIORITIES AND PLANS; 4) DEVEL OP AND IMPLEMENT A PROCESS AND OUTCOME EVALUATION PLAN TO MEASURE THE IMPACT OF IMPLEMENTING STRATEGIES TO PREVENT MULTIPLE FORMS OF VIOLENCE AND ADDRESS SOCIAL AND RACIAL INEQUITIES; 5) OBSERVE DECREASED RATES OF MULTIPLE FORMS OF VIOLENCE, DECREASED SOCIAL AND RACIAL INEQUITIES, AND IMPROVEMENT IN HEALTH AND SOCIAL OUTCOMES RELATED TO ACES.OUTCOMES: SHORT-TERM: 1.1 INCREASED IMPLEMENTATION OF CPTED AND PPP AS STRATEGIES TO ADDRESS MULTIPLE FORMS OF VIOLENCE. 1.2 INCREASED REACH OF CPTED AND PPP AS VIOLENCE PREVENTION STRATEGIES. 1.3 INCREASED IMPLEMENTATION OF CPTED AND PPP AS STRATEGIES THAT ADDRESS HEALTH AND RACIAL INEQUITY. 2.1 INCREASED AWARENESS ABOUT THE INTERSECTION BETWEEN VIOLENCE, SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH, AND RACIAL INEQUITY. 2.2 ENHANCED ACTIVITIES IN THE MULTNOMAH COUNTY COMPREHENSIVE TEEN DATING VIOLENCE AND YOUTH VIOLENCE PREVENTION PLAN. 2.3 INCREASED COORDINATION AND COLLABORATION BETWEEN MCHD, THE CAB, AND YAB TO PROMOTE SUSTAINABILITY. 3.1 INCREASED EVALUATION AND TRANSLATION, ACCESS TO, AND TRACKING OF DATA. INTERMEDIATE: 1.4 DECREASED RISK AND INCREASED PROTECTIVE FACTORS FOR MULTIPLE FORMS OF VIOLENCE. 2.4 INCREASED ENGAGEMENT AND COMMITMENT BY THE CAB AND YAB TO PREVENT VIOLENCE IMPACTING ADOLESCENTS AND YOUNG ADULTS. 2.5 INCREASED ALIGNMENT WITH STATE-LEVEL VIOLENCE PREVENTION PRIORITIES/PLANS, INCLUDING RAPE PREVENTION & EDUCATION (RPE), CORE STATE VIOLENCE & INJURY PREVENTION PROGRAM (SVIPP), AND COMPREHENSIVE SEXUALITY EDUCATION. 2.6 INCREASED CAPACITY OF CAB AND YAB TO PREVENT MULTIPLE FORMS OF VIOLENCE. 3.2 INCREASED SHARING AND USE OF DATA TO FACILITATE ACTION AMONG PROJECT PARTNERS, COMMUNITY, AND DECISION-MAKERS AND FOR CONTINUOUS PROGRAM IMPROVEMENT FOR CPTED AND PPP. LONG-TERM: 1. SUSTAINED, WIDESPREAD IMPACT, AND FAR-REACHING IMPLEMENTATION OF CPTED AND PPP. 2. DECREASED RATES OF MULTIPLE FORMS OF VIOLENCE. 3. IMPROVED HEALTH AND SOCIAL OUTCOMES LINKED TO ACES. 4 DECREASED INEQUALITIES IN POWER, ACCESS, OPPORTUNITIE

GA PREVAYL - PROJECT ABSTRACT SUMMARY TITLE: PREVENTING VIOLENCE AFFECTING YOUNG LIVES (PREVAYL)  APPLICANT: GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR: CLAIRE LISCO PHONE: 678-273-6587 EMAIL: CLAIRE.LISCO@DPH.GA.GOV YOUTH VIOLENCE IS THE INTENTIONAL USE OF PHYSICAL FORCE OR POWER TO THREATEN OR HARM YOUNG PEOPLE AGES 10-24. IT HAS SERIOUS AND LASTING EFFECTS ON THE PHYSICAL, MENTAL, AND SOCIAL HEALTH OF YOUNG PEOPLE. HOMICIDE IS THE 2ND LEADING CAUSE OF DEATH FOR GEORGIANS AGES 15-24 AND THE 4TH LEADING CAUSE OF DEATH FOR AGES 10-14. FOR BLACK MALES, IT IS THE NUMBER 1 CAUSE OF DEATH FOR AGES 15-24 IN GEORGIA. THROUGH PREVAYL THE GEORGIA DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH INJURY PREVENTION PROGRAM (DPH IPP) WILL ADDRESS MULTIPLE FORMS OF VIOLENCE IMPACTING ADOLESCENTS AND YOUNG ADULTS IN COMMUNITIES EXPERIENCING HIGH RATES OF VIOLENCE. THE FOCUS OF THIS APPLICATION IS TO IMPLEMENT COMMUNITY AND SOCIETAL-LEVEL STRATEGIES IN THE SOCIAL ECOLOGICAL MODEL (SEM) TO ADDRESS SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH, HEALTH AND RACIAL INEQUITY, AND PROMOTE COMMUNITY COHESION AND RESILIENCY. DPH IPP WILL LEVERAGE THE EXISTING GEORGIA CHILD ABUSE AND NEGLECT PREVENTION PLAN (CANPP) TO: 1) IMPLEMENT COMMUNITY-LEVEL AND SOCIETY-LEVEL STRATEGIES TO PREVENT YOUTH VIOLENCE IN GEORGIA?S DEPARTMENT OF FAMILY AND CHILDREN SERVICES (DFCS) REGION 5; 2) STRENGTHEN EXISTING COLLABORATIONS AND PARTNERSHIPS TO BUILD AND ENHANCE REGION 5?S JURISDICTIONAL CANPP STRATEGIC PLAN; 3) CONDUCT ASSESSMENTS AND EVALUATION ACTIVITIES TO DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS THAT WILL BE DISSEMINATED TO OTHER COMMUNITIES EXPERIENCING HIGH RATES OF YOUTH VIOLENCE THROUGHOUT THE STATE.ACTIVITY 1 OUTER SEM-LEVEL STRATEGY IMPLEMENTATION: THE GEORGIA PREVAYL TEAM WILL ALIGN THE ATHENS/CLARK COUNTY PUBLIC HEALTH DISTRICT TEEN MATTERS CLINIC EFFORTS WITH REGION 5?S JURISDICTIONAL CANPP STRATEGIC PLAN IN SUPPORT OF FOUR PROJECTS TO CREATE PROTECTIVE COMMUNITY ENVIRONMENTS, PROMOTE SOCIAL NORMS AGAINST VIOLENCE AND AD VERSITY AND STRENGTHEN ECONOMIC SUPPORTS FOR FAMILIES. THE PROJECTS INCLUDE: A) CREATING REGIONAL COORDINATION BETWEEN THE TEEN MATTERS CLINIC AND THE COMMUNITIES IN SCHOOLS AND NEIGHBORHOOD LEADERS PROGRAM TO INCREASE ENGAGEMENT AROUND ISSUES IMPACTING YOUTH VIOLENCE INCLUDING SCHOOL CLIMATE AND SAFETY, ACCESS TO ECONOMIC OPPORTUNITY, AND REDUCED ENGAGEMENT WITH THE JUVENILE CRIMINAL JUSTICE SYSTEM AND COMMUNITY-LEVEL EXPOSURE TO RISKS IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES; B) IMPLEMENTING THE I2I WHAT R U LOOKING 4 (DATING MATTERS) PROGRAM; C) LAUNCHING A MARKETING CAMPAIGN FOR THE GEORGIA TEEN TEXTLINE; AND D) CONDUCTING FINANCIAL LITERACY AND STABLE PARTNERING RELATIONSHIP CLASSES. ACTIVITY 2 STRATEGIC COLLABORATION AND SUSTAINABILITY: THE GEORGIA PREVAYL TEAM WILL PARTNER WITH THE DFCS REGION 5 CANPP MULTI-SECTOR COALITION AND THE SAFETY AND COMMUNITY STABILITY ACTION TEAM TO UPDATE THEIR CURRENT CANPP PLAN TO ADDRESS YOUTH VIOLENCE PREVENTION ACTIVITIES. ACTIVITY 3 PROGRAM EVALUATION: THE PREVAYL TEAM WILL DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT AN EVALUATION PLAN THAT ADDRESSES ALL STRATEGIC ACTIVITIES, INCLUDING PROCESS AND OUTCOME MEASURES. THE EVALUATION DATA WILL BE ANALYZED AND USED TO DEVELOP RECOMMENDATIONS FOR PROGRAM IMPROVEMENT AND PRIORITIZATION. FINDINGS ON DEVELOPING RECOMMENDATIONS AND CANPP ACTION PLANS WILL BE DISSEMINATED TO THE 13 OTHER DFCS REGIONS.

SALINAS CA WILL PREVAYL OVER VIOLENCE AFFECTING YOUNG LIVES - SALINAS CA IS CHANGING THE NARRATIVE FROM THAT OF VIOLENCE, RACIAL INEQUITIES AND NEGLECTED INFRASTRUCTURE TO THAT OF A THRIVING AND PEACEFUL COMMUNITY.  THE MONTEREY COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT'S (MCHD) STRYVE PROGRAM PROPOSES TO CONTRIBUTE TO THIS VISION BY IMPLEMENTING CRIME PREVENTION THROUGH ENVIRONMENTAL DESIGN (CPTED) TO IMPROVE THE SOCIAL AND BUILT ENVIRONMENTS, "THAT'S NOT COOL," A SOCIAL MEDIA CAMPAIGN TO PREVENT TEEN DATING VIOLENCE AND DIGITAL DATING ABUSE, AND BY PARTICIPATING IN SEXUAL ASSAULT AWARENESS MONTH TO PROMOTE HEALTHY RELATIONSHIPS AND HELP FOR VICTIMS.  THESE STRATEGIES WILL IMPACT INTIMATE PARTNER, TEEN DATING AND YOUTH VIOLENCE OVER THE NEXT 5 YEARS.  IN ADDITION TO THESE STRATEGIES, STRYVE WILL CONDUCT EVALUATION AND PERFORMANCE MEASUREMENT, CONTINUE TO COLLABORATE WITH THE COMMUNITY ALLIANCE FOR SAFETY AND PEACE (CASP), UPDATE THE SALINAS STRATEGIC WORK PLAN, AS WELL AS OUR CURRENT SUSTAINABILITY PLAN.  MCHD IS PROUD TO WORK WITH OUR LATINO YOUTH, IN ZIP CODES 93905 AND 93906 THROUGH THEIR TWO NEIGHBORHOOD SCHOOLS, TO ENSURE CAMPUS SAFETY AND THAT OF THE SURROUNDING NEIGHBORHOODS.  BY CREATING PROTECTIVE COMMUNITY ENVIRONMENTS, THIS PROPOSAL WILL ENABLE YOUTH AND YOUNG ADULTS TO ENJOY HEALTHY RELATIONSHIPS AND GATHER IN SAFETY.  EXPERIENCE IN IMPLEMENTING VIOLENCE PREVENTION STRATEGIES OVER THE LAST 10 YEARS, EXPERTISE IN EVALUATION AND ABILITY TO TRANSLATE THE SUCCESSES OF CASP, BUILDING HEALTHY COMMUNITIES AND MCHD MAKES THE STRYVE PROGRAM UNIQUELY QUALIFIED TO CONTINUE THIS WORK THROUGH PREVAYL.

ALASKA YOUTH VIOLENCE PREVENTION PROJECT - YOUTH VIOLENCE IS A SIGNIFICANT PUBLIC HEALTH PROBLEM IN ALASKA. THE STATE EXPERIENCES ONE OF THE HIGHEST INJURY RATES IN THE NATION. ALASKA IS OFTEN RANKED HIGHEST RATE OF SUICIDE, RAPE, AND IN THE TOP 10 FOR INJURY AND HOMICIDE, WHICH RESULTS IN DEATH, HOSPITALIZATION, AND PRE-MATURE LOSS OF LIFE AND PRODUCTIVITY. VIOLENCE PREVENTION REMAINS UNDER-RESOURCED, MINIMIZING THE POTENTIAL IMPACT OF COMMUNITY- AND STATE-BASED INTERVENTIONS. FOR MULTIPLE REASONS, INCLUDING THE VERY RECENT HISTORY OF COLONIZATION WHICH DISRUPTED TRADITIONAL FAMILY AND SOCIETAL STRUCTURES WITH RACISM AND ABUSE, THE REGION OF SOUTHWEST ALASKA, SPECIFICALLY THE TOWNS OF BETHEL AND DILLINGHAM, IS A HIGH-RISK COMMUNITY WITH ELEVATED RATES OF VIOLENCE, SUICIDE AND PROFOUND ECONOMIC HARDSHIP. ALASKA COMMUNITIES EXPERIENCING THESE DISPROPORTIONATE RATES OF VIOLENCE HAVE DEMONSTRATED INCREDIBLE RESILIENCE AND RETAINED MANY STRENGTHS FROM WHICH PREVENTION STRATEGIES HAVE BEEN AND COULD CONTINUE TO BE BUILT. ALASKA IS PROPOSING TO ADDRESS MULTIPLE FORMS OF VIOLENCE INCLUDING YOUTH VIOLENCE, TEEN DATING VIOLENCE, AND OTHER ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCES (ACES) FOR TEENS AND YOUNG ADULTS AGES 13-24. ALASKA WILL IMPLEMENT AT TWO COMPLEMENTARY VIOLENCE PREVENTION STRATEGIES AIMED AT ADDRESSING THE COMMUNITY AND SOCIETAL LEVELS OF THE SOCIAL ECOLOGICAL MODEL TO IMPROVE ADOLESCENT HEALTH ALIGN WITH CDC TECHNICAL PACKAGES FOR VIOLENCE PREVENTION.  ALASKA?S SELECTED PREVENTION STRATEGIES 1) PROMOTE SOCIAL NORMS THAT PROTECT AGAINST VIOLENCE THROUGH A PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT AND EDUCATION CAMPAIGN FOR YOUTH AGES 13-24 IN SOUTHWESTERN ALASKA AND 2) CREATE PROTECTIVE ENVIRONMENTS THROUGH YOUTH LED OUTREACH AND COMMUNITY-NORMS MOBILIZATION INTERVENTION CALLED, ?LEAD ON!? BY BUILDING YOUTH VIOLENCE PREVENTION CAPACITY TO ADDRESS SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH AND RACIAL INEQUITY IN PARTNERSHIP WITH ALASKA NETWORK ON DOMESTIC VIOLENCE AND SEXUAL ASSAULT. ALASKA HAS A STRONG UNDERSTANDING OF THE PUBLIC  HEALTH APPROACH TO VIOLENCE PREVENTION AND HAVE EXPERIENCE IMPLEMENTING ADOLESCENTS AND YOUNG ADULT VIOLENCE PREVENTION STRATEGIES.  ALASKA IS BUILDING ON EXPERTISE AND CAPACITY TO IMPLEMENT VIOLENCE PREVENTION PROGRAMMING THROUGH A PARTNERSHIP BETWEEN THE ALASKA DIVISION OF PUBLIC HEALTH?S ADOLESCENT HEALTH PROGRAM AND THE ALASKA NETWORK ON DOMESTIC VIOLENCE AND SEXUAL ASSAULT WITH EVALUATION SUPPORT FROM STRATEGIC PREVENTION SOLUTIONS.   THESE ACTIVITIES ALIGN WITH CURRENT COLLABORATIVE EFFORTS WITH PARTNERS INCLUDING ALASKA STATEWIDE VIOLENCE AND INJURY PREVENTION PARTNERSHIP, DELTA AND RAPE PREVENTION EDUCATION PROGRAM ACTION PLANS,  HEALTHY ALASKANS 2030 VIOLENCE RELATED INDICATORS, AND THE PATHWAYS TO PREVENTION STATEWIDE STEERING COMMITTEE. ALASKA APPROACH OF ENGAGING YOUTH WILL RESULT IN WIDESPREAD IMPACT BY DECREASING RATES OF VIOLENCE IMPACTING ADOLESCENTS AND YOUNG ADULTS IN COMMUNITIES DISPROPORTIONATELY BURDENED WITH HIGH RATES OF VIOLENCE IN ALASKA. THE IDENTIFIED ALASKA PREVAYL PROGRAM OUTCOMES ARE GROUNDED IN A THEORY OF CHANGE AND ENGAGING METHODOLOGY FOR PLANNING, PARTICIPATION, AND EVALUATION TO PROMOTE AND SUSTAIN SOCIAL CHANGE. THE OUTCOMES OF THIS FUNDING WILL RESULT IN DECREASED  RATES OF VIOLENCE IN RURAL COMMUNITIES, SPECIFICALLY SOUTHWESTERN ALASKA. THERE WILL BE AN INCREASE IN ACCESS TO YOUTH-LED OPPORTUNITIES AND SOLUTIONS IMPLEMENTED FOR RURAL ALASKA COMMUNITIES.

MINNEAPOLIS HEALTH DEPARTMENT: PREVENTING VIOLENCE AFFECTING YOUNG LIVES - BASED ON MANY QUALITY OF LIFE MEASURES, MINNESOTA IS OFTEN CITED AS ONE OF BEST PLACES TO LIVE IN THE US. HOWEVER, THOSE MEASURES BELIE SIGNIFICANT RACIAL DISPARITIES. IN MINNESOTA, PEOPLE OF COLOR FACE SIGNIFICANTLY WORSE OUTCOMES IN MANY AREAS. AS THE STATE?S LARGEST CITY, MINNEAPOLIS HAS A ROLE IN DRIVING THOSE RACIAL DISPARITIES. COMPARED TO THE REST OF THE STATE, MINNEAPOLIS ALSO EXPERIENCES HIGHER LEVELS OF VIOLENT CRIME. WITHIN MINNEAPOLIS, THE BURDEN OF VIOLENCE BECOMES EVEN MORE DISPROPORTIONATE BASED ON GEOGRAPHY AND RACE. MINNEAPOLIS YOUTH ARE DEEPLY IMPACTED BY THIS. IN 2019, HOMICIDE ACCOUNTED FOR 39% OF DEATHS AMONG YOUTH AGE 15 TO 25 IN MINNEAPOLIS. PREVAYL PRESENTS AN OPPORTUNITY TO IMPLEMENT COMMUNITY-LEVEL APPROACHES TO PREVENTING MULTIPLE FORMS OF VIOLENCE. IT ALSO PRESENTS AN OPPORTUNITY TO CRITICALLY CONSIDER THE INTERSECTIONS BETWEEN RACIAL INEQUITY AND VIOLENCE.   THIS PROJECT WILL FOCUS ON ADDRESSING VIOLENCE IMPACTING YOUNG PEOPLE AGES 10-24 LIVING IN MINNEAPOLIS. ADDITIONAL FOCUS WILL BE ON YOUNG PEOPLE LIVING IN PARTS OF NORTH AND CENTRAL/SOUTH MINNEAPOLIS WHERE THE BURDEN OF VIOLENCE AND POVERTY ARE THE HIGHEST. IT WILL COMPLEMENT EXISTING YOUTH VIOLENCE PREVENTION STRATEGIES OPERATING AT THE INDIVIDUAL AND RELATIONSHIP LEVELS OF THE SOCIAL-ECOLOGICAL MODEL. TWO NEW COMMUNITY LEVEL APPROACHES?A PUBLIC ENGAGEMENT INITIATIVE CALLED MINNEAPOLIS VIOLENCE PREVENTION COMMUNITY CHAMPIONS (MVPCC) AND A SCHOOL-BASED APPROACH CALLED BUILDING PEACEFUL SCHOOLS (BPS)?WILL BE INTRODUCED.CONTRACTED PARTNERS WILL INCLUDE NONVIOLENT PEACEFORCE, MINNEAPOLIS PUBLIC SCHOOLS, AND COMMUNITY-BASED EXPERTS SERVING AS TRAINERS. WORK WILL BE COORDINATED WITH ADVISORY GROUPS SUCH AS MINNESOTA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH?S (MDH) RPE-FUNDED PROGRAM, MDH?S MN COMMUNITY LEVEL PREVENTION ACTION COLLABORATIVE, A YOUTH VIOLENCE PREVENTION COALITION, A VIOLENCE PREVENTION STEERING COMMITTEE, A PROJECT IMPLEMENTATION TEAM, AND A TO-BE-CREATED STUDENT PEACE ADV ISORY GROUP.PROJECT-SPECIFIC SHORT-TERM OUTCOMES UNIQUE TO OUR CHOSEN STRATEGIES TO BE ADDRESSED WITHIN THE FIRST TWO YEARS INCLUDE INCREASES IN: UNDERSTANDING OF RISK AND PROTECTIVE FACTORS ASSOCIATED WITH MULTIPLE FORMS OF VIOLENCE; KNOWLEDGE OF THE PUBLIC HEALTH APPROACH TO VIOLENCE PREVENTION AND HOW RACISM, INEQUITY AND DISPARITIES IMPACT VIOLENCE; NONVIOLENT CONFLICT RESOLUTION; KNOWLEDGE OF ACES; AND NEW AND AUTHENTIC CONNECTIONS. PROJECT-SPECIFIC INTERMEDIATE OUTCOMES UNIQUE TO OUR CHOSEN STRATEGIES TO BE ADDRESSED WITHIN THREE TO FIVE YEARS ARE: INCREASED LIKELIHOOD TO TAKE INDIVIDUAL ACTION TO PREVENT VIOLENCE; LIKELIHOOD TO ENGAGE WITH OTHERS IN COLLECTIVE VIOLENCE PREVENTION WORK; SENSE OF COMMUNITY CONNECTEDNESS AND BELONGINGNESS; POSITIVE PERCEPTIONS OF PHYSICAL AND EMOTIONAL SAFETY; PEER ACCOUNTABILITY; NUMBER OF SITUATIONS WHERE DE-ESCALATION INTERVENTION OCCURRED; DECREASED SCHOOL SUSPENSIONS OR DISCIPLINARY REFERRALS; AND POSITIVE EDUCATIONAL OUTCOMES. IN ADDITION, THE PROJECT WILL INCLUDE REVISION OF THE CITY OF MINNEAPOLIS?S VIOLENCE PREVENTION STRATEGIC PLAN AND A FOCUS ON SUSTAINABILITY. PROCESS AND OUTCOME EVALUATION ACTIVITIES WILL BE USED TO ENSURE THAT MAJOR COMPONENTS OF THE GRANT?STRATEGIC PLAN ENHANCEMENT, COLLABORATION, SUSTAINABILITY, MVPCC AND BPS?ALIGN WITH PROJECT GOALS AND OBJECTIVES.

BOSTON PUBLIC HEALTH COMMISSION PREVAYL - THE PROPOSED BOSTON PREVAYL IS LED BY THE BOSTON PUBLIC HEALTH COMMISSION (THE CITY?S HEALTH DEPARTMENT) AND ENGAGES A DIVERSE AND COMMITTED GROUP OF PUBLIC AND PRIVATE PARTNERS WITH STRONG LINKS TO OUR FOCUS POPULATION OF YOUTH AND YOUNG ADULTS AGES 10-24 AND THE NEIGHBORHOODS IN WHICH THEY LIVE. THE PROJECT BUILDS ON THE GOALS AND STRATEGIES OUTLINED IN THE ?CITY OF BOSTON VIOLENCE PREVENTION AND INTERVENTION PLAN,? THE CITY?S 2020 ROADMAP FOR ADDRESSING VIOLENCE THROUGH THE PUBLIC HEALTH LENS OF PREVENTION, INTERVENTION AND RESPONSE.THE PURPOSE OF BOSTON PREVAYL IS TO ADDRESS MULTIPLE FORMS OF VIOLENCE IMPACTING ADOLESCENTS AND YOUNG ADULTS IN BOSTON. THE TARGET POPULATION FOR THIS PROJECT ARE YOUTH AND YOUNG ADULTS AGES 10-24 IN BOSTON, THE GREAT MAJORITY OF WHOM ARE BLACK, LATINX OR ASIAN, AND MANY OF WHOM BELONG TO LOWER-INCOME FAMILIES.BOSTON PREVAYL WILL PURSUE THREE OVERALL STRATEGIES DURING THE PROJECT PERIOD: (1) ENHANCE AND SUSTAIN CITYWIDE STRATEGIC PLANNING FOR VIOLENCE PREVENTION. (2) CONDUCT PEER-LED ACTIVITIES THAT EDUCATE AND ENGAGE YOUTH AND YOUNG ADULTS ON DATING VIOLENCE, HEALTHY RELATIONSHIPS AND VIOLENCE PREVENTION. (3) CREATE PROTECTIVE ENVIRONMENTS FOR YOUTH AND YOUNG ADULTS BY INCREASING THE CAPACITY OF YOUTH- AND FAMILY-SERVING AGENCIES TO UNDERSTAND AND ADDRESS THE INTERSECTION BETWEEN VIOLENCE AND SOCIAL DETERMINANTS OF HEALTH AND RACIAL INEQUITY, AND ITS IMPACT ON ADOLESCENTS AND YOUNG ADULTS.THE PROPOSED PROJECT LEVERAGES THE WORK OF A DIVERSE GROUP OF PARTNERS COMMITTED TO VIOLENCE PREVENTION, YOUTH DEVELOPMENT AND RACIAL EQUITY. AT THE CENTER OF THIS COLLABORATION IS OUR MULTI-SECTOR COALITION: THE BOSTON YOUTH RESILIENCY & RECOVERY COLLABORATIVE. CURRENTLY FUNDED THROUGH A GRANT FROM THE US DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE, THE GOAL OF THE COLLABORATIVE IS TO SUPPORT BOSTON YOUTH AND FAMILIES AFFECTED BY THE OPIOID CRISIS AND SUBSTANCE USE BROADLY THROUGH THE CREATION OF A CITYWIDE, DATA-DRIVEN, CROSS-SECTOR COLLABORAT IVE PLAN TO CATALYZE POSITIVE COMMUNITY AND SYSTEMS CHANGE.

NJ ACES PREVENTION PROJECT: LEVERAGING A STATEWIDE COMMITMENT TO IMPROVE OUTCOMES FOR NJ CHILDREN AND FAMILIES - THE CENTER FOR HEALTH CARE STRATEGIES (CHCS) IS PROPOSING TO LEAD A MULTI-PRONGED, MULTI-STAKEHOLDER EFFORT TO ENHANCE NJ’S CAPACITY TO MONITOR, REDUCE, AND PREVENT ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCES (ACES). THE PROJECT WOULD ADVANCE CORE PREVENTION STRATEGIES TO PROMOTE SOCIAL NORMS CHANGE THAT PROTECT AGAINST VIOLENCE AND ADVERSITY AND ENSURE A STRONG START FOR CHILDREN. CHCS HAS ENGAGED A RANGE OF STATE AGENCIES AND OTHER DATA LEADERS WITHIN THE STATE THAT – WHEN BROUGHT TOGETHER – WILL ENABLE NJ TO ENHANCE ITS CURRENT ACE SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM – CURRENTLY LIMITED TO THE STATEWIDE NJ STUDENT SURVEY (YRBS) AND THE BRFSS. THIS WILL ENABLE US TO IDENTIFY COMMUNITIES AT HIGH RISK FOR ACES, AND THEREFORE POSITION US TO INTERVENE MORE EFFECTIVELY TO PREVENT THEM. ULTIMATELY, THESE EXISTING DATA SOURCES WILL BE AUGMENTED THROUGH THE DEVELOPMENT OF SEVERAL CROSS-SECTOR, INTEGRATED DATA SOURCES FOR WHICH CONCEPTUAL DISCUSSIONS AND EARLY PLANNING ARE UNDERWAY. THE PROJECT HAS AN EXPLICIT FOCUS ON IDENTIFYING ADOLESCENTS AT HIGH RISK OF ACES AND LEVERAGES PROGRAMS AND POLICIES RELATED TO PRENATAL, EARLY CHILDHOOD, SCHOOL-AGE POPULATIONS, AND DELIVERS ACE TRAINING AND EDUCATION AND WOULD BE IMPLEMENTED WITH THE SUPPORT OF THE OFFICE OF THE FIRST LADY AND A NEWLY FORMED NJ ACE INTERAGENCY TEAM, COMPRISED OF SENIOR LEVEL OFFICIALS ACROSS STATE GOVERNMENT. THIS BUILDS ON THE ONGOING NJ ACES ACTION PLAN EFFORT - WHICH CHCS IS LEADING, ON BEHALF OF THE NJ DEPARTMENT OF CHILDREN AND FAMILIES AND THE NJ FUNDERS ACE COLLABORATIVE (COLLECTIVELY, REFERRED TO AS THE NJ ACE COLLABORATIVE). WE WOULD TIME THE FORMAL RELEASE OF ACTION PLAN TO COINCIDE WITH THE ENGAGEMENT OF DATA AND PROGRAMMATIC PARTNERS TO LAUNCH THE WORK. THE FIVE CORE STRATEGIES OF THE ACTION PLAN REFLECT SEVERAL OF THE CDCS ESSENTIALS OF CHILDHOOD GOALS AND WERE DRAFTED EARLIER THIS YEAR BASED ON THE INPUT OF FAMILIES AND STAKEHOLDERS WHO PARTICIPATED IN A SERIES OF FOCUS GROUPS AND LEARNING LABS ACROSS T HE STATE, REFLECTING OUR COMMITMENT TO CENTER THE VOICES OF NJ FAMILIES AND COMMUNITIES. IN COLLABORATION WITH THE PARTNERS LISTED, CHCS PROPOSES TO ACHIEVE THE FOLLOWING OUTCOMES DURING THE 3-YEAR PROJECT PERIOD: INCREASES IN (1) CAPACITY TO COLLECT, REPORT AND USE ACE DATA; (2) SYSTEM AND PROGRAM PARTNERS’ UNDERSTANDING OF THE DISPARATE BURDEN ON VARIOUS POPULATIONS TO TARGET ACE PREVENTION EFFORTS; (3) PUBLIC UNDERSTANDING ABOUT ACES; THE NUMBERS OF PROFESSIONALS, COMMUNITY LEADERS, AND FAMILY MEMBERS TRAINED/EDUCATED ABOUT ACES; (4) UNDERSTANDING ABOUT POSITIVE PARENTING TECHNIQUES AS AN ALTERNATIVE TO CORPORAL PUNISHMENT; (5) NUMBERS OF FATHERS PARTICIPATING IN FATHERHOOD ENGAGEMENT EFFORTS; AND (6) THE NUMBER OF STATE AGENCIES ADOPTING TRAUMA-INFORMED POLICIES, AND INCORPORATING ACE PREVENTION STRATEGIES INTO THEIR PROGRAMS AND PRACTICES. OUR GOALS WOULD BE ACHIEVED BY (1) DEVELOPING A CROSS-AGENCY SURVEILLANCE SYSTEM FOR IDENTIFYING REGIONS OF THE STATE – AND SPECIFIC FAMILIES WITHIN THOSE COMMUNITIES – AT GREATEST RISK FOR ACES AND CONNECTING THEM TO ACE PREVENTION STRATEGIES; (2) LEVERAGING THE PLANNED ACE PUBLIC AWARENESS AND MOBILIZATION CAMPAIGN TO SUPPORT A ROBUST ACE EDUCATION AND TRAINING EFFORT ACROSS THE PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SECTORS AIMED TO CHANGE SOCIAL NORMS AND INCREASE RESILIENCE; (3) DEVELOPING A NJ ACE PREVENTION COALITION FOR THE STATEWIDE COORDINATION OF THE MYRIAD ACE PREVENTION, REDUCTION AND RESILIENCE EFFORTS, AND SHARING INFORMATION DEVELOPED IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE ACE SURVEILLANCE INFRASTRUCTURE; AND (4) COLLABORATING MEANINGFULLY WITH THE LEADERSHIP OF THE NEWLY ESTABLISHED OFFICE OF RESILIENCE – THE FIRST IN THE COUNTRY – CHARGED WITH BRINGING A FOCUS ON RESILIENCE TO NJ’S HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICE AGENCIES. IF SUCCESSFUL, THIS APPLICATION WILL ENABLE THE STATE TO TARGET ACE PREVENTION RESOURCES MORE EFFECTIVELY; INCREASE

MINNESOTA PREVENTING ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCES: DATA TO ACTION - THE IMPACT OF ACES ON MINNESOTA (MN) YOUTH AND ADULTS IS A SERIOUS PUBLIC HEALTH CONCERN. ACCORDING TO THE 2019 MINNESOTA STUDENT SURVEY, ALMOST HALF OF 8TH, 9TH, AND 11TH GRADE STUDENTS IN MINNESOTA REPORTED ONE OR MORE ACE. THERE WERE DIFFERENCES IN ACE PREVALENCE BY GEOGRAPHY, SOCIOECONOMIC STATUS, AND RACE/ETHNICITY, WITH LOWER INCOME AND STUDENTS OF COLOR REPORTING SIGNIFICANTLY MORE ACES THAN THEIR HIGHER INCOME AND WHITE COUNTERPARTS. THE STRONG DOSE-RESPONSE ASSOCIATION BETWEEN THE NUMBER OF ACES AND A RANGE OF HEALTH BEHAVIORS MAKE PREVENTING ACES A PRIORITY TO MULTIPLE DIVISIONS OF THE MINNESOTA DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH (MDH). WHEN COMPARED WITH STUDENTS WHO REPORTED NO ACES, STUDENTS WITH FOUR OR MORE ACES WERE SIGNIFICANTLY MORE LIKELY TO REPORT ALCOHOL, MARIJUANA, AND PRESCRIPTION DRUG MISUSE, AS WELL AS MENTAL HEALTH OUTCOMES INCLUDING ANXIETY, DEPRESSION, AND SUICIDE IDEATION AND ATTEMPT.THE MINNESOTA PREVENTING ADVERSE CHILDHOOD EXPERIENCES DATA TO ACTION (MN-PACE: DTA) PROGRAM WILL USE A PARTICIPATORY MODEL TO ENGAGE A STATEWIDE STAKEHOLDER GROUP, INCLUDING OTHER STATE AGENCIES, COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS, COMMUNITY MEMBERS, AND DECISION-MAKERS IN SUSTAINABLE AND EFFECTIVE WAYS TO 1) ENHANCE OUR EXISTING STATE SURVEILLANCE INFRASTRUCTURE FOR ACES, WHICH CURRENTLY FOCUSES ON DATA FROM THE MINNESOTA STUDENT SURVEY, TO INCLUDE NEW AND INNOVATIVE DATA SOURCES INCLUDING DATA ON PROTECTIVE FACTORS AT THE COMMUNITY, NEIGHBORHOOD/SCHOOL, FAMILY, AND INDIVIDUAL LEVELS IN ORDER TO IDENTIFY APPROPRIATE TARGET COMMUNITIES AND IMPROVE PREVENTION EFFORTS; 2) IMPLEMENT EVIDENCE-BASED STRATEGIES TO PREVENT ACES THAT WORK WITH MN?S STRENGTHS AND FOCUS ON CHALLENGES IDENTIFIED BY INDIVIDUAL COMMUNITIES THAT ARE READY TO MAKE CHANGES; AND 3) USE THE MN SURVEILLANCE INFRASTRUCTURE TO INFORM SELECTION AND IMPLEMENTATION OF EVIDENCE-BASED STRATEGIES TO PREVENT ACES AMONG ALL MINNESOTANS AND PARTICULARLY AMONG HIGH-RISK TARGET POPULATIONS, SUCH AS AMER ICAN INDIANS AND FAMILIES IMPACTED BY INCARCERATION. OUR LONG-TERM GOALS INCLUDE PREVENTING ACES NOW AND IN FUTURE GENERATIONS, TO BREAK THE INTERGENERATIONAL CYCLE OF ACES, AND TO PREVENT FURTHER TRAUMA AMONG THOSE WHO ALREADY EXPERIENCED ADVERSE EVENTS BY BUILDING PROTECTIVE FACTORS IN THEIR LIVES. MDH WILL WORK TO MEASURE AND MEET THE SHORT-TERM OUTCOMES AFTER YEAR 1 AND CHANGE IN INTERMEDIATE OUTCOMES IN YEARS 2 AND 3. SHORT TERM OUTCOMES INCLUDE INCREASED ACCESS AND AVAILABILITY OF TIMELY STATE AND LOCAL DATA FOR USE IN DATA-DRIVEN DECISION MAKING; INCREASED AWARENESS AND UPTAKE OF EXISTING STATE PREVENTION STRATEGIES AND IMPROVED CROSS-SECTOR COLLABORATION; INCREASED EVALUATION AND USE OF DATA FOR ACE PREVENTION, INCREASED AWARENESS OF THE DISPARATE BURDEN OF ACES, AND AWARENESS OF EFFECTIVE PRIMARY PREVENTION STRATEGIES. INTERMEDIATE OUTCOMES INCLUDE IMPROVED MONITORING OF TRENDS IN ACE INDICATORS, INCREASED REACH OF PRIMARY ACE PREVENTION STRATEGIES, PARTICULARLY AMONG HIGHER RISK POPULATIONS, AND INCREASED USE OF DATA IN PREVENTION EFFORTS. WE LOOK FORWARD TO LEARNING AND PRACTICING WITH THE CDC AND OTHER STATE GRANTEES AS WE MOVE MINNESOTANS ON THE TRAJECTORY TOWARD HEALING AND HEALTH.
